PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners do not want a Uranium Enrichment Plant constructed in South-East Queensland because:
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a Uranium Enrichment Plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a Uranium Enrichment Plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a Uranium Enrichment Plant in South-East Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BOLKUS; COATES; COLEMAN; HAINES; KEEFFE; MACKLIN; WALSH
PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
2. many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
3. Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
4. the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will-
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 26 citizens), Coates (from 16 citizens), Coleman (from 43 citizens), Haines (from 657 citizens), Keeffe (from 17 citizens), Macklin ( from 35 citizens) and Walsh (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia repsectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P.:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.9.1982 the amount of principal had only been reduced by $395.06, since 1.10.1981 leaving a balance of $14,609. 94.

(2) Your petitioners therefore request that the Government immediately make available similar generous terms to the many thousands of home buyers in Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to abnormally high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of Australia in Parliament Assembled. This petition of certain citizens of Australia concerned with continuing cuts in Federal Government funding of higher education respectfully showeth that the Federal Government cut-backs in funding have:
made it increasingly difficult for many Australians to contemplate study at a university or college of advanced education.
reduced the resources available to groups with particular needs such as our Aboriginal and Ethnic communities.
seriously jeopardized Australia's ability to keep pace with and contribute to technological developments in a whole range of areas.
reduced the quantity and quality of community education programs offered, especially in rural colleges.

forced universities and colleges of advanced education to cut back on the numbers of staff available to teach existing courses endangering the quality of education offering and narrowing the range of courses available.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that your Honourable Senate:

ensure that levels of government funding for education are at a level that will enable all Australians to undertake the higher education of their choice regardless of their personal financial circumstances.
provide all students, present and future, with adequate financial assistance by way of allowances and scholarships.
will make a firm commitment to oppose the re-introduction of any tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to Press comment during the week that employees of industries which close up for up to six weeks during the summer will be paid unemployment benefit if they have no entitlement to holiday pay over that period and are unable to find work during that period? Is is a fact that these people who have had no payment at that time for many years will now be eligible for unemployment benefit? If this is so, will the Minister make a statement on this matter and arrange for specific instructions to be included in the Unemployment and Sickness Benefits Manual so that we do not have the difficulty that sometimes arises because some officers of the Department do not know what the new rules are?
—I will examine the matter raised by the honourable senator and ensure that clear instructions are available to the relevant officers of my Department.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D: PRODUCTION OF ARMY RECORDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your guidance in relation to the powers and operations of Estimates committees. When the supplementary estimates for the Department of Defence are dealt with in the next quarter I will seek from the Army the attendance of the psychologist who approved the recruitment of two recently convicted murderers, Corporal Robin Reid and Private Paul Luckman. I will also want their personal records produced and an overall examination made of Army psychological services. Mr President, do you know of any means by which the Army can refuse that request when Estimates Committee D meets?
—I will look into the matter raised by the honourable senator and give him a response.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Has the Taxation Office adopted certain strategies deliberately to delay taxation refunds for returns submitted for the 1981-82 financial year? Can the Minister provide information on a State by State basis of the number and value of taxation refunds issued for each month since and including July and, as a comparison, for the same months in 1981?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no reason to think that there is any different approach to the assessing and returning of refunds to those who are eligible for them than has occurred in any other year. If there is some problem I will see that the Senate is advised about it. As far as I am aware there is no reason why there should be any undue delay. If the figures that are requested on a State by State basis are readily available I will also see that Senator Colston is advised.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations been drawn to a story on AM this morning in which the manager of finance and planning of Esso Australia Ltd said that Australia had 'grave industrial relation problems' that were making this country 'less attractive for investment than it had been 10 years ago'? Is the Minister further aware that strikes at Esso's Gippsland operation have cost the company $ 40m in lost income and a drop in production of 20 per cent and that Esso estimates that this, in turn has cost the Commonwealth and State governments some $560m in lost revenue? In view of this fact, what action does the Government intend to take in order to stop the rapacious actions of waterfront and seamen's unions which are holding up coastal shipping in 10 ports and four States, which have cost Queensland Alumina Ltd $2 1/2m over the past six weeks and which are stopping oil shipments to and from Port Stanvac in South Australia ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the comments which were made on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM this morning, although I did not actually hear the program. With respect to the various questions asked by Senator Jessop I can only agree that disputes, whether they touch the oil industry or prevent the free movement of Australian imports and exports, are very serious and costly to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jessop will appreciate that I cannot verify the precise figures in dollars which Esso claims to have lost and which it claims the Government has lost because of strikes within Australia. But it is certainly true that strikes of the sort mentioned do have a considerable effect not just on the private companies or the private enterprise bodies which are involved and the workers who lose wages; indeed, there is also a clear loss of revenue to the Government. I think Senator Sir John Carrick would be able to give more detail than I can on the loss of revenue which has been occasioned because of the holding up of oil production in Australia, the losses that we sustained in connection with the oil levy.

Senator Jessop mentioned current maritime disputes in his question. I can advise the Senate that the River Boyne which was held at Gladstone for several weeks because of demarcation disputes has now sailed, is returning to that port and is expected to resume its normal operations. The dispute about the River Boyne was the subject of a number of Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings. The parties concerned are committed to further talks which are aimed at reaching total resolution of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deputy Commissioner McKenzie solved that one, I think.

—I think there are still to be talks between the parties. But as I said before, the ship is back in operation and it is hoped that it will continue in its normal operations henceforth. There is another serious dispute involving a number of maritime unions manning tugs at various Australian ports which is causing many ships to be delayed. The matter of dispute there concerns hours of work or rostered days off. The issues have been argued before a Full Bench of the Commission and a further hearing has been set down for 17 December. It is quite clear that there is very little gained by anybody, and indeed a great deal lost, both by strikes and by failing to comply with the requirements of the Arbitration Commission. Certainly if we get continued industrial action in this field it will continue to damage Australia's reputation as a reliable trader. That is something which we can ill afford in these very difficult economic times.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns a report which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Three Melbourne emergency aid services have recently closed, unable to cope with the increased demands of the poor.
The report continues:
Many more are under heavy pressure, and the Salvation Army, despite having recently curtailed the distribution of its family handout, plans to cut the handout from $25 to $20 after Christmas.
The report states that Ms Merle Mitchell, who chairs the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee, said:
. . . she knew of staff giving their lunches away to families with hungry children.

As the Minister would know, the three services that have closed are the Springvale Community Aid and Advice Bureau, Broadmeadows Care and the North Richmond Family Care Centre. Has the Minister or his Department any plans to rectify this situation? If there is to be a wage freeze, does the Minister contemplate that some of the funds saved there from might be redirected into these welfare channels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the matters raised by Senator Chipp. I do not think there is any prospect of a direct diversion of funds from the wage freeze to welfare agencies of this sort. Rather, the Government is seeking to direct any savings which can be effected by a wages pause to capital works-which will be employment creating. As Minister for Social Security I support what I see as a very strong welfare element in that. Undoubtedly the major cause of pressure on the welfare agencies mentioned by Senator Chipp is the increase in unemployment. Indeed, the report to which he referred makes that point. Even staunching the increase in unemployment is an important element from the welfare viewpoint.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth's involvement in emergency relief is relatively modest. For the last three or four years we have put half a million dollars into emergency relief Australia wide. That is a very small proportion of the total commitment to emergency relief around Australia. Traditionally that has been a matter which has been handled by State governments and voluntary agencies. It is a fact that the Victorian Government is rather less involved in the provision of emergency assistance than most State governments, so I think this is an area where some additional State activity would be warranted.

I expect to be making decisions shortly concerning the distribution of about $ 125,000 to Victorian agencies. I think I am awaiting a recommendation from the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee at the moment. But in any event that is something which should occur shortly. A more substantial contribution though, which will, I think, impact favourably upon the sorts of agencies mentioned and upon the Victorian Government-there are some hundreds of welfare agencies in Victoria, I think some 600 or more-is the new mortgage and rent relief assistance which we are providing. Victoria will be getting, I think, $5.3m this year, which is a comparatively large sum in those fields. This contribution will be matched by the State Government and the money will be spent on mortgage and rent relief, which is usually a very important component of the requests which are made for emergency relief by people who are having difficulty in managing. This represents a very significant increase in emergency relief capacity in Victoria to which the Commonwealth is contributing 50 per cent.

As far as the Commonwealth's responsibilities are concerned, there have been requests that we should become more heavily involved in the emergency relief field. In general, I have adopted the view on behalf of the Government that emergency relief should remain a matter for State governments and voluntary agencies with the Commonwealth commitment being to maintain as best it can an adequate income maintenance system which will remove the need for emergency relief as far as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Government taken the Liberal victory in Flinders as significant public reinforcement of the wage freeze proposal initiated by the Commonwealth Government? Does the disastrous failure of the Australian Labor Party in the Flinders by-election put to rest the barrage of half-baked arguments put up by Opposition senators in Question Time over recent weeks? Is it not still true that any economic policy to gain public support must be openly responsible, balanced and consistent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that the electors of Flinders judged the Liberal Party as being the party that could produce the best economic management for Australia. That judgment was made, and it was a clear judgment. Within that judgment, and since the Australian Labor Party attempted to lift up the wage freeze as an issue, the Flinders victory can be taken as an endorsement by the community of a wage freeze within the economic management program. I have no doubt about that at all. That is taken, by political commentators, to be a fair comment on the result.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government found it necessary again to revise its estimate of the Budget deficit? Has the Government received advice from Treasury about the size of the deficit? What is the current estimate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — This morning, at the meeting of the Premiers, the Treasurer advised-I would think it is in order for me to make this matter public on his behalf-the revised estimate of the Budget deficit for the 1982-83 year. The Treasurer mentioned a figure that could be in the vicinity of $4,000m as the deficit for this year. That figure was cited by him as being based on the most up to date estimate of revenue and expenditure in the current year.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, relates to the dairy industry. I ask the Minister: Are the present equalisation arrangements between export and domestic returns appropriate as we move into the 1980s? What is the situation on cheese imports, bearing in mind that European Economic Community imports are coming into this country at a rate which has increased by 38 per cent in two years? Why is there no effective import controls and anti-dumping legislation? What effect are these matters having on the industry, which is presently trying to price itself on the domestic market at a level which gives reasonable returns to the producer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a series of questions relating to the dairy industry. It is a fact that there have been many adjustments within that industry over the last 10 years. Ten years ago milk production was over seven million litres, and last year it was a little over five million litres. This has brought about a very significant restructuring of that industry. We are going into the 1980s with a smaller industry, but it is a stronger one and it relies on export markets to a lesser extent than it did 10 years ago. So there is probably less danger now of domestic market disruption occurring in the absence of equalisation arrangements than in the past. It is worth noting, I think, that the Government recently referred to the Industries Assistance Commission the question of assistance to the Australian dairying industry. One of the matters that I expect the Commission to examine is the relevance of equalisation schemes in the current environment.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen also asked about the situation of cheese imports and pointed out that EEC imports are coming into the country at a rate which has increased by 38 per cent in two years. It is a fact that consumption of cheese in Australia has been increasing but imports have been increasing at a faster rate than consumption. The local industry believes that it can produce the products to meet fair import competition but it is, of course, concerned about the prospect of dumping or any other form of unfair competition. In regard to imports of cheese from the EEC at subsidised prices, complaints were filed last week under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. If dumped or subsidised exports are found to be harming the local industry, corrective action will follow immedately. Discussions have also been opening up with the EEC with a view to having restitutions on cheese exports to Australia withdrawn.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen also asked why there is no effective import controls and anti-dumping legislation. It is the belief of the Government that the anti- dumping legislation is effective, although it has been announced recently that it is to be strengthened. Indeed, we will have amending legislation in the Senate soon. Senator Bjelke-Petersen will have a chance to support that legislation in this place. We anticipate that that will increase the effectiveness of the anti-dumping arrangements in this country. The last part of the question asked what effect all these matters are having on the industry. Obviously, the industry is concerned at the current level of imports and at what it sees as unfair competition. The Government is committed to ensuring that unfair import competition does not drive down returns from the producer. That does not mean to say that there will be an end to competition from imports but rather that we should look to having an end to unfair competition and, in particular, to any dumping which may be found to have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My quesion is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has this Government reversed its former objections to the public funding of elections? What was the total cost to the Australian taxpayer of the pro- Government family Budget commercials screened on television during the by- election in Flinders? Does the Minister not agree that the three stage exercise- that is, watching television, buying a newspaper and then sending away a completed coupon before getting any information-is plain gimmickry, designed to deter rather than to help people get benefits? How can this Government justify this dishonest spending of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money on a program which is nothing more than election propaganda which costs the Liberal Party nothing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I totally disagree with the suggestion of gimmickry that is made by the honourable senator. He should ask his Victorian colleagues about the advertising which was taking place in Victoria which featured the Premier of Victoria at a time when State by-elections were proceeding. The fact of the matter is that the Government announced a whole range of changes to programs which were of benefit to the Australian community. On a number of occasions it has been drawn very forcefully to my attention that there is a need to publicise those programs. For example, at the Housing Ministers conference the point was made very forcefully by both Labor and Liberal Ministers present that there was a need for an advertising campaign to draw to the attention of home purchasers the benefits which are available in Commonwealth programs. I made the point to those Ministers that that could be seen as political advertising. In response to my point they reaffirmed that they thought the advertising was necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition spokesman, Senator Grimes, has suggested that the Department of Social Security needs to use a wider-ranging and more sophisticated type of advertising and that it should not just rely on newspaper advertising, although he has, of course, objected to the precise form of advertising we followed. The rationale for advertising by the Department of Social Security is that there is a great range of benefits and clients that it wishes to contact. To do that by tightly directed advertising to each group would result in our needing to take up virtually the whole of the advertising time on every television station. The use of television was, therefore, simply to draw attention to the other mediums of advertising which could give more detailed information. The newspaper advertisements, in turn, indicated that detailed information could be obtained from my Department either by contacting the Department, by writing or by sending in a coupon, in which case material would be sent out. Indeed, we have had a pretty good response to that. I have no difficulty in justifying that spending. I have done a number of things which were specifically suggested by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—Senator Grimes, for example, suggested that we should use women' s magazines. I am sure he will be pleased that the Australian Women's Weekly issued a supplement showing the range of social welfare benefits which are available following the Budget. He suggested that we should use television. We have used television. Quite frankly, we will go on using it. Let me make it quite clear that we will also be using the ethnic Press because another substantial area of difficulty has been in ensuring that benefits are understood by our very large immigrant population. I will get the precise figures. The advertising campaign was not run by my Department, except that it contributed to that part of the campaign which was relevant to social security matters. I will get the figures relevant to my Department and give them to the honourable senator. I would welcome even more specific suggestions than I have had in the past as to how we should go about the quite difficult task of ensuring that people who are entitled to benefits have their attention drawn to them. We have used a range of measures. We have used enclosures with cheques, we have used advertising on television and in the newspapers and we have used direct mailing. I am open to suggestions as to how else we can ensure that there are no gaps between my Department and the people who are entitled to benefit from its programs.
—You are a phoney, Chaney.
—Order Senator Grimes! I ask you to withdraw that language. It is totally unparliamentary to call any honourable senator 'a phoney'.
—Good heavens, I will withdraw, but it is becoming a bit like a Sunday school picnic if we have to withdraw things like that.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs heard of a broadcaster cum journalist by the name of Claudia Wright, nee Clarke, formerly of Bendigo, Victoria, but now resident in the United States of America as the Washington correspondent of the New Statesman and married to second husband Melbourne-born Harvard PhD Dr John Helmer? Is this Claudia Wright the person who launched, as recently as 13 November on Australian Broadcasting Commission radio from Washington, a violent attack on President Reagan and his Administration, accusing them of lying, cheating, lusting and of liquidating their personal opponents?
—It would be true, wouldn't it?

—Is she a supporter of yours too? Is this the same Claudia Wright who is the supporter and apologist for the murderous Colonel Gaddafi and his Libyan hit squads who are mentioned in the newspapers today? Is this Claudia Wright--
—She is not too keen on Menachem Begin either.

—Is she also a supporter of yours? Is this Claudia Wright the person who has deliberately put at risk the lives of Western intelligence officers by naming them in the United States and is now prohibited from naming them there? Is she coming to Australia in order to name them whilst she is here? Can the Minister confirm or deny the rumor that this person is about to return to Australia and is to be given the opportunity by some Melbourne radio station to spew her lies and racist hatred on the Melbourne people?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator who has just asked this question repeatedly used the word 'lies'. When I used that word in this chamber I was suspended. I suggest that the honourable senator incur the same penalty as I incurred or that my penalty be withdrawn and I be exonerated.

—Order! There is a big difference between the two cases. If the honourable senator looks at the Standing Orders he will find that he cannot make inferences about honourable senators or members of parliament. There is no point of order. On this occasion reference was made to somebody outside the Parliament . I take this opportunity of reminding all honourable senators that on many occasions, particularly this session, opportunity has been taken of the privilege of this chamber to pass derogatory remarks in this chamber about citizens outside it. I ask all honourable senators to take note of that in future.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I know that Senator Lewis has a rather inventive mind but I do not understand how the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, would have any responsibility--
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Sit down.

—Order! I will handle things from the chair; I do not need assistance from honourable senators. On many occasions similar types of questions have been posed by honourable senators from both sides of the chamber to Ministers within this chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that Senator Lewis is seeking information from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as to whether some of the information that he gave in his question was correct. On behalf of the Minister I am not able to confirm or deny whether a news broadcaster called Claudia Wright is returning to Australia. I will seek information from the Minister. I will see also whether he has any comment on a connection between the person concerned and the other matters mentioned by Senator Lewis.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES AIR FORCE B52 BOMBERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seen the report in last week's Age which claims that when a United States B52 bomber exploded at the end of a runway at Castle Air Force base near Los Angeles the flash was visible for 32 kilometres and no one knew whether the plane was carrying nuclear weapons? Can the Minister assure the Australian people that the United States Air Force B52s which fly into and over northern Australia are not carrying nuclear weapons and that if a similar accident should happen here a nuclear disaster will not result?

—I did not see the article to which Senator McIntosh drew our attention. I can assure the Australian people that, as Senator McIntosh well knows, there are fixed arrangements between Australia and the United States as to the training flights that are being undertaken by B52s with American manned crews over Australia. The honourable senator can be assured that under those arrangements there is no possibility of the US Air Force carrying nuclear weapons on those flights.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support. I refer to the financial difficulties of International Harvester Australia Ltd. How many factories in Australia are capable of manufacturing heavy trucks? What will be the effect on Australian defence industrial capacity if International Harvester is forced to close down?

—I understand that there are quite a number of manufacturers of heavy duty trucks in Australia, including Leyland, Ford, Leader, Mack, Volvo and Mercedes-Benz, in addition to International Harvester. The Government is hopeful , of course, that International Harvester will be able to trade out of its present problems and that economic benefits will accrue to all. The company has incorporated a relatively high degree of Australian content in its vehicles; nonetheless, the benefits which could accrue from the company's retention amongst a number of similar Australian firms could not be supported purely on defence grounds. In other words, the economics come into it.

—Did the Minister for Education read an article in Saturday's Age newspaper concerning new restrictions on the provision of subsidies for non- government schools? If so, can he say whether the report was accurate. If schools now in the most needy category are to have controls placed on the disposal of their private income, why are these controls not to be applied universally across the non-government school sector and particularly to the wealthiest schools in receipt of the largest private income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the article which appeared in Saturday's Age, but it was reported to me that there had been an article. My understanding is that the article in the Age has caught up some months after the event with a decision taken by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and endorsed by me regarding procedures which should be put into place to make the already rigorous testing of income even more rigorous in 1983. I think the journalist concerned was Mr Tom Ormonde. He came across something which had been ignored or missed by other journalists.

ANSWER.PARA: Since all non-government schools get a basic grant for each student, it is those schools which receive more than the basic grant which need their income tested. The schools that get only the minimum level will not get any less. Since they get the minimum level of grant anyhow, income testing is not an issue for them. It is for those schools that want to get more than the minimum grant that the procedures need to be applied. That is the reason why it has been decided to apply to all those seeking more than the minimum grant the more rigorous procedures laid down by the Schools Commission. As I said, these decisions were taken quite some time ago. We agree that the public interest requires that the rigorous testing already in place should be made even more effective. That is the reasoning behind the proposals which I believe were reported on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. In view of a clearly documented and totally established dumping case having been dismissed because the Australian manufacturer concerned did not hold a large share of the market and because the particular product represented only a small part of the company's total output, can the Minister undertake to press for amendments so that small and developing Australian industries can achieve similar treatment to that of large industries so that they may be given a reasonable opportunity to become established under a reasonable trading climate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the question asked by the honourable senator touches on the amendments which are to be brought into this place. I will ask the Minister to consider the point which he has raised. I have some information which I think is relevant to the question on the applications to the Federal Court of Australia under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act concerning decisions under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. The Court has not proceeded to a full hearing of the facts in any case so far. Finality has been reached in three cases in circumstances other than the Court proceeding to a hearing. In one case the applicant has withdrawn, has agreed to give security to the Australian Customs Service in another case and has requested the Court to withdraw the injunction and dismiss its application in a third.

ANSWER.PARA: The proceedings have resulted in each instance from decisions by the Comptrollers-General of Customs to require provisional measures in respect of imports for which there has been a finding of a prima facie case of dumping or subsidisation and consequent material injury to Australian industry and where the cases were considered to require provisional measures for the duration of the investigation of the complaint. Whether the history of these shows any fundamental defect is a matter which is not clear to me. I do not think it does. I will ask the Minister to consider the need for any further amendments and to give a further answer to the Senate.

I stress that the Government sees it as important to have effective anti- dumping measures in place in 1982. Clearly the world trading conditions are such that there must be a very great temptation on exporters of both manufactured and other goods to put them on to the world market at dumped prices. The Government will be concerned to ensure that Australian producers are not subjected to unfair competition through this means.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOVIET NAVAL PRESENCE IN PACIFIC AND INDIAN OCEANS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In some respects it follows Senator McIntosh's question about American Service aircraft. Did the Minister see the Weekend Australian report which stated that Russia has 500 naval ships in the Pacific using new ports in Vietnam ? Did the Leader also see the report on the same page that the former President of France, Giscard d'Estaing, said that the Third World War has begun between the Soviet Union and the United States of America? Is the Government pleased, therefore, that ANZUS is alive and well and that American forces are using Australian facilities for our joint defence against increasing Soviet pressure in the Pacific and Indian Oceans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read the article in the Weekend Australian to which Senator Martyr referred. It is a fact that Russia today has the largest, the most modern and the most rapidly growing naval force in the world. The evidence is that it has moved its forces progressively both into the Indian Ocean and into the Pacific Ocean. The victory for the communists in Vietnam was a significant victory for the dispersal of communist forces in the Pacific and elsewhere. It enabled the USSR to get a warm water port; Vladivostok is an icebound port for a large part of the year. Access to Cam Ranh Bay is the direct result of the victory for communism in Vietnam. It has enabled the USSR to disperse its forces and therefore to offer a significant threat in terms of an imbalance of forces in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Under those circumstances ANZUS becomes of enormous importance. It is the linchpin of the Australian defence system. It is the one assurance that we can have that in the Pacific Ocean there can be some balance. I stress that the communist victory in Vietnam and the securing of what was an American naval port, Cam Ranh Bay, has enabled Russia to get a naval port of immense strategic significance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WHEAT SALES TO THE UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade fiasco last month and Mr Anthony's concern about the effects of even higher trade barriers on Australia's agriculture exports. Did the Australian Wheat Board Chairman seek Government permission to negotiate a long term wheat contract with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? Why was it necessary for the Board to seek Government approval for doing the job it is obliged by statute to do, that is, sell Australian wheat? Has permission been granted to negotiate the long term contract or is the Australian Government, as well as foreign governments, impeding the sale of Australian agricultural exports?

—I understand that the Wheat Board sought the advice of the Government on whether there were any policy restrictions to prevent the Board from entering into discussions on a long term wheat contract with the USSR wheat marketing authority. The Board was concerned that, in the highly competitive international market, Australia is the only substantial supplier that does not hold a long term contract with the USSR for the supply of wheat. That sort of long term agreement or understanding is a recognised feature of the Board's marketing strategy. Such agreements will be of particular importance when Australia's wheat production returns to normal. Sadly, that will not be a problem in 1982. The Minister for Primary Industry has advised the Chairman of the Board that it is a matter for commercial judgment as to the nature of the arrangements it pursues for future wheat sales to the Soviet Union. Any long term arrangement with the USSR wheat marketing authority should be discussed in the context of normal commercial negotiations.
—Then why did he have to ask the question?

—Just so there is no misunderstanding in the Senate, I commenced the answer to the question by saying that the Australian Wheat Board was simply seeking the advice of the Government on whether there are policy restrictions. The advice of the Government clearly indicated that it was free to make a commercial judgment in the matter. It was a request for information on the part of the Board, or so I am informed.

—Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to the report in the Daily Mirror of 2 December headed ' Mountain truck plunge-Radioactive Crash Alert'. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the facts of the incident and the nature of the radioactive material, or was that report just another sensation-seeking headline?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article in the paper and immediately sought details. The accident happened at 11.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 1 December, when a truck carrying general merchandise crashed through a side rail of a safety ramp at Mount Victoria and rolled downhill scattering its load. Thankfully, the driver escaped serious injury and reported the incident. The police inspected the area and found a wooden box wedged behind a tree. Partially obscured on the label were the words 'anger Uranium'. The police, I think rightly, assumed that that might mean 'Danger Uranium', and notified the Atomic Energy Commission. It in turn notified the New South Wales Health Commission's relevant division. I am happy to say that the words on the box were 'Ranger Uranium'. Having been checked first with a geiger counter for safety reasons, it was found to contain stainless steel tubing and flanges. So in fact it was a consignment of ordinary materials on behalf of Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd. But I do not reflect upon the natural caution of the authorities there. They did the sensible thing. Happily, it was not radioactive material, and the incident is concluded.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Two weeks ago he was asked what was, in the present economic circumstances, the upper limit of a responsible deficit. He declined to answer, although he always seems to know what an irresponsible deficit is. I ask again: What is the responsible limit? Is it the all time record of $4 billion now forecast, or is it whatever figure the Fraser Government finally produces? Will he table the detailed revised estimates of receipts and expenditure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week when I was asked that question I said that the Government had determined a particular Budget figure, but that two matters had occured following that--
—Determined by cooking the books, by falsifying the evidence.

—I also remind Senator Walsh that following attempts by others to say that, I stressed that the figures in the Budget were supplied by the Department of the Treasury. They are not Cabinet induced figures. They are in fact the figures supplied. Indeed, I repeat that, specifically for the one major variable of unemployment, the figures are supplied by the Department of the Treasury.
—And then fiddled by the Treasurer. He admitted it.
—I take exception to that remark.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw because that is a reflection upon the Treasurer.
—It is no more than the Treasurer himself admitted in the House three weeks ago.
—Order! I am asking you, Senator Walsh, to withdraw the word ' fiddled'.
—The test of acceptability in this House, of course, is the Standing Orders and not the truth, and on that basis I will withdraw.
—I ask you for an unconditional withdrawal.
—I withdraw, but only because I want to hear his answer, his latest excuse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, that is not an unconditional withdrawal.
—I did not hear the final words.
—He said he will withdraw but only because he wants to hear my answer.
—Order! Senator Walsh, I ask you for an unconditional withdrawal.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I repeat that last week when I was asked a question I said that the Government had brought down a Budget that it considered had a very acceptable deficit, a conservative deficit, and that the figures in that Budget were given to the Government by the Treasury and not altered by the Government. The figures were supplied by the bureaucracy in this Government. Subsequent to that was the onset of a drought of immense consequences. No one could have predicted and still no one can predict the extent of the drought. Nevertheless, the Government has estimated the cost of the drought at $356m or $357m. Subsequently, unemployment rose at a rate and in a nature that had not been anticipated either by Treasury or the Government, particularly among mature aged and married people, with the result that not only the numbers but also the quantum of money for unemployment enlarged. As a result of that, it is necessary for the Government to do what must be done, that is, provide unemployment benefits. On both drought relief and unemployment benefit the Government is responding as it must.

ANSWER.PARA: The ideal deficit is one that will not bring undue pressure upon the money supply or upon interest rates. The Government had sought to have such a deficit, but due to an act of nature-the drought-and the pressure of overseas recession upon this country in terms of unemployment it has not been possible to obtain an optimum deficit. The Government has revised the deficit. It is very unhappy that it should be approaching $4,000m. Clearly, that will put pressure upon its refinancing and upon the loan market in borrowing and, therefore, a pressure on interest rates that we would not want. Of course, we do not like a deficit of that size. But in judging the deficit I remind the people of Australia that it is of a magnitude that was not in any way found unacceptable by people such as Mr Hawke and other spokesmen of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The changed estimates for unemployment benefit and the increased expenditure on drought relief accounts for $356m of the now admitted blowout of $2,324m. In view of that, will the Leader of the Government produce a letter signed by the Treasury Secretary stating that all the Budget Estimates were prepared by Treasury and that Treasury accepts responsibility for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this place I will speak for the Government on these matters. I hope that honourable senators will accept that what I say happens to be the truth. I will not seek a letter from the Treasurer. I would be perfectly happy to seek a breakdown of the figures in due course. I should have added that , because of the slackening within the economy, one of the other things that has added to the increase in the deficit is a fall-off in revenue.
—Because you watered down your own tax legislation.

—I must repeat the facts, again and again. Senator Walsh plays this little game of seeking to defy the Chair all the time. The figures that the Budget was constructed upon were given by the departments concerned, and notably by the Treasury. The figures on which unemployment estimates were based were Treasury figures. Neither Treasury nor anyone else could have anticipated the harsh onset of the world recession or the drought. As a result of that, of course it has been inevitable for the Budget to blow out. That is, in itself, serious because of the upward pressures it puts upon interest rates.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment say whether the 41 per cent of voters who were supposed to have voted 'No Dams' on their ballot papers in the Flinders by-election was a legitimate official percentage or a figment of the imagination of one of the scrutineers who perhaps had Tasmanian Wilderness Society sympathies?

—I read the newspaper reports which indicated that there had been a certain write-in of votes. I understand that these include words such as 'No Dams' and 'Ned Kelly'. Because there is no policy of counting these votes I think that no one would be able to give an official estimate of the extent of such a vote. It remains a matter of conjection and, I suppose, the best estimates of scrutineers at any particular polling place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I too have heard of instances of delays in the processing of applications. I am not aware whether the Minister has taken any special action in recent days. I note Senator McClelland's suggestion that the Public Service Board be asked to give consideration to any additional assistance which may be required. I will seek from the Minister his response to the question and any other information that he is able to give. —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, relates to the River Boyne, the new Australian National Line ship which is under charter to Queensland Alumina Ltd for the Weipa-Gladstone alumina trade, and an idiotic, petty dispute over whether a seaman or a shipwright should operate a forward mooring winch. Is the Minister aware that the Merchant Service Guild of Australia, the union to which the shipwrights belong, has defied four different determinations by an arbitration commissioner that the winch should be operated , on mooring, by seamen? As this lawlessness has tied up the ship for seven weeks, has cost Queensland Alumina over $2.5m as of Friday of last week, in ship charges alone, and has occasioned the Comalco company in considerable additional expense at Weipa, which will lead to the retrenchment of some of its labour force in the near future, I ask: How many more jobs has the Merchant Service Guild to destroy and how much more damage has to be done to the Australian economy before the Government is prepared to deregister this union?

—This is the second time that this dispute has been mentioned during Question Time. I can well understand the concern which is felt by the honourable senator about the losses which are sustained by individuals and the economy generally. The dispute to which the honourable senator referred is the tying up of the vessel known as the River Boyne. It was held at Gladstone for some weeks and this caused significant losses. The vessel has now sailed and is expected to resume its normal operations. The question of the deregistration of the union evidences the strong dissatisfaction which would be felt not only by Senator MacGibbon but also by everyone who has been watching this dispute or who has been affected by it. I will refer the question to Mr Macphee for his consideration. I assume that, since the dispute has now been dealt with and it is hoped that normal operations will resume, the dispute is unlikely to be the focus for any particular Government action.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry that the Minister has been misinformed. The dispute has not been resolved in any way at all. The fourth determination by the arbitration commissioner was defied by the Merchant Service Guild. The position now is that the ship, which was in passage to Sydney, is returning to Gladstone, where it will have to be bunkered. The position of the Merchant Service Guild is exactly the same as it has been for the last seven weeks. I ask: Apart from expressions of sympathy and concern, what is the Government prepared to do?
—As I said, I will refer the question to Mr Macphee and ask him for a response.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer recall the document widely circulated and published by the Liberal Party secretariat describing the Australian Democrats proposed Budget of last August as 'a recipe for economic collapse' because it suggested a Budget deficit of the order of $4 billion? Why has a proposition which was regarded as 'a recipe for economic collapse' in August now been embraced by the Government, as disclosed in the Minister's answer to a question this afternoon when it was admitted that the deficit has now blown out to the order of $4 billion? Will the Minister admit that a deficit of the scale I proposed back in August would have stimulated the economy at that time, re-employed tens of thousands of Australians and reduced inflation without putting undue stress on interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The present projected deficit of about $4 billion results from the present economic circumstances. In part it relates to additional expenditure that has been undertaken and announced. It results also from lower receipts in almost every area of government revenue. The downturn in the economy and the shedding of employment have resulted in lower pay-as-you- earn collections than were projected. It has resulted in lower sales tax collections. Provisional tax collections on company profits are also expected to be considerably lower than was projected at the time of the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget proposals put forward by the Australian Democrats bear little relevance to the present economic circumstances. The fact that the Democrats happened upon a $4 billion deficit at the time of the Budget does not relate to the circumstances leading to the now projected figure for 1982-83. The Treasurer , in the context of discussing these matters with the Premiers this morning, released the figure that has recently been given to him. There are people who, in the context of those discussions, imagine that a further billion dollars or two billion dollars on the deficit would not really make any difference to the present economic circumstances. Many of them held that view when they thought the Budget deficit would be about $2 billion. Therefore, I think that if we are looking at figures at any particular time we need to look at the elements that constitute both sides of the Budget and result in a deficit. What was proposed at the time of the August Budget was a realistic figure on the projections that were given to us at that stage. The downturn in the economy has been at a much more rapid rate than I think anyone expected. Certainly, the shedding of employment has been at a much more rapid rate than anyone would have expected.

I do not know whether the Budget proposals of the Democrats would have had the miraculous stimulus that the Democrats envisaged, given the overseas situation and the unavailability of expanding markets for us. So, I think we need to look at what was projected at the time our Budget was formulated and what is now the reality of a number of factors that have changed since that time. The fact that two figures seem to be the same does not mean that our Budget and the one proposed by the Democrats bear great comparison.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED SOCIAL SECURITY CONSPIRACY CASE: DR NICOLAEDIS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another matter which was raised by Senator Grimes last Thursday in Question Time concerned the role of a Dr Nicolaedis in the review of former Greek invalid pensioners which was undertaken by an Australian medical team in Athens last month. Senator Grimes implied in his question that the review team' s results would be biased against the pensioners and he queried the involvement of Dr Nicolaedis in light of his earlier involvement in these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Following Senator Grimes's question I sought detailed advice from my Department on the matter and can now inform the Senate that there is no substance to the allegations in the question. I am advised that prior to the medical review team's departure for Greece, it stated that it would require the services of an interpreter familiar with medical terminology. The selection of interpreters and external Greek specialists was left, by necessity, to the discretion of staff at the Australian Embassy in Athens who have the requisite local knowledge. The services of a Greek panel doctor, Dr Nicolaedis, were accepted for interpreting duties on the basis that the doctor had been used by the Australian Government for several years. The identity of the doctor was not known to my Department. I would say, however, that the medical review team had no reservations about Dr Nicolaedis and commended the way in which he undertook his strictly limited and defined duties.

In view of Senator Grimes's question, it is worth stressing that Dr Nicolaedis 's role as an interpreter was deliberately confined by the team to interpreting duties. The medical review team has advised that he did not attend the team's discussions on the findings of any examination, nor did he take part in the preparation of reports or recommendations to the Director-General of my Department. The team has stated categorically that Dr Nicolaedis was entirely neutral in his role of interpreter. Dr Nicolaedis is a radiologist and, on occasions, he was requested to take additional X-rays as requested by the review team. The team has commented that the X-rays provided were manifestly of the patients in question and the quality of the X-rays were found to be entirely satisfactory. It is most important to note that Dr Nicolaedis was not asked and did not provide any evaluation of the X-rays he took. This evaluation was left entirely to the review team which was itself competent in this area. Again, Dr Nicolaedis was not present at such discussions.

I think it is clear that Dr Nicolaedis's involvement in the earlier reviews has not influenced in any way the course of the current review. Consideration is currently being given by the Director-General to the team's findings. I suggest to Senator Grimes that when the outcome of those findings is known he may wish to speak with me further on the matter. The allegations put forward by Senator Grimes last week were first advanced to the Australian Embassy in Athens by the Greek-Australian Pensioners' Association in Greece during the team's examinations. The allegations were rejected by the medical review team. I am proposing to make copies of the correspondence available to Senator Grimes today.

In view of the very great effort that has been made by my Department to ensure a careful re-examination of these cases under the most objective conditions, I have made that fairly full response to the question because I would want any queries which are raised to be answered both to the satisfaction of Senator Grimes and to the satisfaction of any members of the public who are interested in the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: RESEARCH FACILITIES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 25 November Senator Teague asked me a question about the information resources of the Department of Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following response to Senator Teague's question. Professor Millar's article in the publication Australian Foreign Affairs Record makes a number of favourable comments on the Department' s operations and effectiveness. There is no doubt that the professional operations of the Department require readily accessible information and research materials, as well as trained and experienced officers capable of offering the highest standard of advice to Ministers and an effective service to the public. The Department maintains a standard filing system, which suffices for most tasks, and a specialist library. Officers also have ready access to background documents and publications covering the range of foreign affairs interests.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department has substantially upgraded its information distribution and retrieval system through the application of computer technology to the Diplomatic Communications Network. A study is now being made of the possibilities of using computer technology to cover other departmental documents so that information retrieval would be improved over existing filing systems. The effectiveness of departmental advice depends heavily on the day to day assessment and advice of our missions overseas, which monitor and report on issues and developments of direct concern to Australian foreign policy. This is one of the most efficient and responsive areas of departmental activity, the effectiveness of which has been enhanced by the application of new techniques.

The Department attempts to encourage as much specialisation of its officers as is practicable, whether in functional areas or on the basis of their geographical experience, thereby retaining and building upon their expertise for application both overseas and in Australia. Staffing policy is also aimed at ensuring that officers in key policy areas in the central office spend longer periods there between overseas postings. At the same time, the rotation of officers between home and overseas postings needs to be balanced to maintain an effective foreign service overall. A recent development in the Department is an agreement in principle by the Public Service Board to a reorganisation of the Department's top structure. One result of this will be to restore a policy planning role to the Department and relate this more closely to the overall advancement of Australian strategic interests.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Progress Report on the River Murray: Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Government's response to the Progress Report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on the River Murray tabled in the Senate on 2 December 1982.

I regret that I was not in the Senate at the time of the presentation of the Government response. I was not informed about it and therefore I sought leave to take note of the paper today. I regard this report as quite important and regret very much that it took 12 months for the Government to respond to it. The Committee went to Adelaide, having been alerted to the closure of the River Murray mouth at that time. It considered that as a matter of public interest and urgency it should do so. The Committee submitted its report in November 1981 and it has taken 12 months for the Government to respond. I should like the Government to take note of that criticism because it is not the first time that chairmen of committees have risen in this place and requested that more attention be given by the Government to responding far earlier to these important reports.

The response took the form of a letter written to me on 11 November by the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick. One or two of the Committee's recommendation were accepted. Among them was 1 (a) which stated:
The River Murray Commission be empowered to undertake an integrated and comprehensive approach to the problems of the River Murray.

I think the Government has responded in part to that recommendation, perhaps not as fully as we would like it to; but at least the River Murray Waters Agreement has been altered to a degree that the River Murray Commission now has some more say as far as water quality is concerned. Recommendation 1 (b) states:

The Commonwealth and State Governments should consider the establishment of a national body to determine water quality standards and to set guidelines with respect to future development along all Australian river systems.

That recommendation was contained in an earlier report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment which dealt with a progress report on the River Murray. It was also a recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution headed by former Senator Davidson a number of years ago. As indicated in the report that we have presented it was also recommended by the former South Australian Government, under Premier Tonkin. The report stated:

The South Australian Government sees the problem facing the River Murray as a serious national one in which the Commonwealth Government must take the lead for its early resolution. The South Australian proposal is based on the Commonwealth Government initiating the necessary works and measures which will enable the Commonwealth and the New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments , through the River Murray Commission, to manage the River Murray in concert and in harmony and in such a way that both the rights of the three States and those of all users of the River Murray are protected. The South Australian Government in its Bicentennial proposal has also recognised that a permanent solution to the problems of the River Murray has been frustrated by the Australian consititutional framework.
The report continued:

The Committee therefore recommends that the Commonwealth Government give serious consideration to the proposals put forward by the South Australian Government aimed at achieving a permanent solution to the River Murray salinity problem.

I believe it is still quite important that the Government deal with those recommendations, particularly now when there is a drought. Unless we come to grips with the challenge that is thrown out with respect not only to the River Murray system but also, as out report states, to all river systems in Australia, I am afraid that by the year 2050 the development of this country will be seriously impeded, if it has not stopped altogether. I think it is a matter that transcends individual States and the Commonwealth. It is a national problem with which we need to deal. I asked a question about the Delaware River Basin Commission three weeks ago last week. I suggested that that was an example of co -operative federalism. The Commission has extraordinary powers and seems to be managing quite well despite the fact that four or five States are involved as well as the Federal Government.
