TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory (Self- Government) Amendment Bill 1982 was introduced into the House of Representatives in the first sitting week of the Budget session, which session is now in its fourth month. It has taken that considerable period to move across King's Hall for the consideration of the Senate. I think that is but an indication of the way in which the Government has developed its program in this place over the last three to four months. However, having said that, the Opposition indicates that it does not intend to oppose the Bill, which naturally follows and seeks to make a number of adjustments to the principal Act of 1978 which gave self- government to the Northern Territory. I suppose it is natural that there needs to be some amendments following the operation of the original act.

SPEECH.PARA: The major function of the Bill is to confirm and clarify the rights of the Commmonwealth in respect to minerals on lands which were reacquired by the Commonwealth Government after the declaration of self-government for the Northern Territory. It is natural that mineral rights over those lands should be vested in the Federal Government. The Bill also deals with the length of time prior to a general election in which a vacancy in the Legislative Assembly must be filled. It deals also with indemnifying the Treasurer in respect of loans which the Treasurer has given a guarantee. The Opposition does not quibble with the legislation on that point, but we wonder why there is a need to remove sub- section (7) from section 47. It is conceded that it is a discretionary sub- section and that it allows the Commonwealth Treasurer to ask for an indemnity in exchange for a guarantee, should the Treasurer require that. Another amendment will in fact move some of the sections of the Act more towards self-government provisions. So in that sense, it is part of the evolution of self-government in the Northern Territory.

The Bill will increase the number of people who can have dormant warrants, but basically it has been introduced in this House in order to protect Commonwealth rights over Commonwealth lands in the Territory against the issue of mining leases or the use of land for that type of purpose. It is a provision which may well be necessary in other forms of legislation in respect of Commonwealth land, but this provides what we see as adequate protection for the land in that area.

The Bill also gives the Commonwealth, and rightly so, clear rights and clear authority over minerals found in Commonwealth land. Therefore, the Commonwealth has control over mining of this land. Of course, the question of mining is very vexed. It has been very vexed in respect of the Northern Territory, because when we talk about mining any of our natural resources there we have to have regard for the rights of the Aboriginal communities, whose living conditions and environment would be drastically altered by such mining development and in many cases would suffer. We also have to have regard for the environmental aspects because a great amount of the land which appears to have mineral resources situated under the surface is in national parks. We also have the problem of the nuclear fuel cycle which the Northern Territory has some particular interest in.

When we talk about mineral rights on Commonwealth land in the Northern Territory we are talking about a number of features which have to be considered. When we talk about it in that sense the question of the mining of uranium is raised. I would like to make some comments to make the position of the Australian Labor Party clear. It is our clear and unequivocal policy that no future uranium mining will be allowed to develop. We will be pulling Australia out of any links in the nuclear fuel cycle. This will involve firstly, the phasing out of current uranium mining commitments and secondly, a refusal to allow further development to go ahead. Labor will be using all its Commonwealth powers to ensure that this policy is carried out.

I mention here also the Labor Party's policy on the situation as it now exists in the Northern Territory, particularly in relation to those important areas I have referred to-environment, Aborigines, the nuclear fuel cycle and national parks. Stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park, which has been a concern of the Senate and particularly of Senator Mulvihill over a long period, was declared in 1975. However, Stage 2, which is a larger area than Stage 1, has yet to be proclaimed. Perhaps the Government recognises its obligations in this area. If it is the Government's intention to declare Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park this Bill will certainly facilitate the process. Traditional Aboriginal land owners through their land trust are required to lease sections of their land in the Alligator Rivers area to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for declaration as a national park. During the complex process of granting Aboriginal land claims and then the establishment of the Kakadu National Park the Fraser Government excised the sensitive areas of Ranger, Jabiluka and Koongara for the purposes of uranium mining. To that extent concern was expressed in the Aboriginal movement, the environment movement and the peace movement in Australia about those moves taken by the Government, particularly as it was for the purpose of uranium mining.

Koongara is now a uranium mining enclave within Stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park. When Stage 2 is declared the Ranger and Jabiluka areas may also become uranium mining enclaves within the Park itself. It is necessary to expedite the full transfer of the Alligator Rivers Aboriginal land claims and to establish Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park including those mines which would not proceed under Labor's anti-uranium mining policy. I am sure there is a concern in Australia for these matters. One has only to look at the writing on ballot papers on conservation matters during the Flinders by-election over this last weekend. I think it is a tremendous event of citizen consciousness when we have 41 per cent of such people commenting on ballot papers-it is true that most of the comments appear to be on Labor ballot papers, but a substantial number of Australian Democrats and Liberal Party people also exercised their right to express that view in a voluntary way during the Flinders by-election. I think that indicates a tremendous concern in the Australian community about conservation issues as they relate of course to South West Tasmania.

Writing on ballot papers is one way in which people on the mainland of Australia have been able to express themselves in a non-legislative way. I think that probably indicates that something like two-thirds of the Australian people feel very strongly about South West Tasmania. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party believes that same concern is expressed about uranium mining. Of course, I am speaking in this debate not only as a result of my concern and my shadow ministerial capacity but also at the request of Senator Robertson who is not here but who is convalescing in hospital after an operation last week. I know that if he is listening to the broadcast he will be endorsing the remarks I am making in respect of these problems because he has expressed concern both within the party and to me personally about his interest in and concern for this legislation and all that flows from it.

The National Parks and Wildlife Service has overall management responsibility for Uluru-Mount Olga National Park, but the Northern Territory Conservation Commission provides day to day management. In the current financial year, 1982- 83, half a million dollars will be allocated by the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory Government for this purpose. Of course, that positive step will be endorsed and continued when a Federal Labor Government is elected in 1983. I think we can concede that there will not be an election in 1982, although there has been no denial of an early election. I think we can say in the latter weeks of this session that the election will take place in 1983. The Labor Party is very confident about what the Australian people will do when the election is held.

There are two more points I want to make briefly before finishing. Firstly, the Government saw fit originally to make the term of the Northern Territory parliament four years and has decided to maintain that. I think honourable senators recall that we, on this side of the House, have attempted this year to take steps towards encouraging the Commonwealth Government to move towards a four-year parliamentary term for the Federal Parliament and to regularise the ways in which electoral reform can be enacted towards stabilising the position in respect of the rights of the Senate and the House of Representatives. We have not always been successful in that, but our objectives have been clearly set out by Senator Evans and by me. Secondly, the section relating to the nomination for parliament and the holding of office is much more reasonable than the one that currently persists for the national Parliament. It allows for the resignation from public office at the time of nomination rather than 14 days prior to nomination, which we are shackled with federally. I am sure that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will agree with me that this is an anomaly. It affects the rights of persons in the Public Service and in State parliaments. There are certain restrictions. This Bill seeks to remedy the situation in respect of the Northern Territory. It is about time that we took those steps nationally to overcome some of those anomalies.

Lastly, I am still at a loss to know why section 71 needs to be amended to allow 'the Northern Territory' to be substituted for 'the Commonwealth' in contracts that may have been drawn up in the last four years. It was concluded that this was necessary, at the time the principal Act was prepared and debated in the Parliament but it was not proceeded with. However, the updating bears no relationship to the other amendments. What contracts, for example, have been drawn up in the last four years that would be affected by this amendment? There was no suggestion in the second reading speech why these matters have now been rectified. It would be interesting to know the intentions of the Government and why it has decided that these changes should now be made.

As I indicated earlier, the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bill. The Bill has a number of machinery provisions which establish the rights of the Commonwealth with respect to mining in the Northern Territory. We think that is a positive step forward. It also removes some of the anomalies which exist as a result of the evolution of self-government in the Northern Territory. To that extent, the Opposition gives this Bill its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for the support they have expressed for the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Amendment Bill. It is a small Bill. It amends the principal Act as has been said by Senator Geitzelt. I think the honourable senator concedes that it does not concern uranium mining or Aboriginal land. It does concern a number of matters relating to self-government in the Northern Territory. I will answer only two points raised by Senator Gietzelt to obviate the need for a lengthy debate in the Committee stage. He asked a question about clause 9 of the Bill, which relates to borrowings other than from the Commonwealth. Our advice is that the section to be deleted is no longer needed. The Commonwealth is adequately protected without that section. The Treasury believes it is no longer needed. For that reason it seems appropriate to delete it from the principal Act. It seems to us to be just a tidying up measure. As the honourable senator said, the matters are not of great consequence, but that is the reason behind that one.

SPEECH.PARA: He also asked about clause 12 which amends section 71 of the principal Act. A number of contracts have been entered into. Three periods are involved. A number of contracts are involved, including simple contracts for cleaning which may have been entered into with the Commonwealth but which properly should be transferred to the Territory for administrative purposes. The provision proposed in clause 12 will simply enable that to happen. With those two explanations, I thank honourable senators for their support and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate briefly that the Opposition supports the Bounty (Berry Fruits) Bill 1982. I do so on behalf of Senator Walsh who is unable to be here today. The Bill provides assistance for the production of fresh berry fruits which are used for processing. An important part of the legislation is that it provides a bounty, and the bounty will be paid to the producers. In essence, it implements the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission in its report of 21 August 1981 entitled 'Fruit and Fruit Products'. A bounty was preferred by the Government in this case because much of the jam and juice manufactured in this country is in fact manufactured from imported fruit. The bounty is payable at the rate of $100 per tonne and is paid directly to the growers based on information provided by the processors. So at least we know that the bounty is to be paid to those who produce the fruit. This is particularly important for the berry fruit producers in Tasmania who produce, apart from strawberries, some 90 per cent of the berry fruits produced. Tasmania has some 250 berry fruit producers.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme will operate for five years from 1 July this year and the cost in the first year is expected to be some $300,000. It is hoped that in this and subsequent years it will provide assistance for the berry fruit producers in this country to improve their technology and their methods generally and to increase their production. This is important, particularly in my State where in recent years berry fruit producers have had a pretty bad time. This is the equivalent of tariff assistance of about 10 per cent, in keeping with the IAC's recommendation.

As I said, the Opposition prefers bounties as a form of assistance. It is to be hoped that this bounty, which has been recommended by the independent inquiry, will assist berry producers in competition with other countries, in particular New Zealand. I am aware that berry growers are worried by imports generally, in particular imports from New Zealand, and about what will happen to those imports after the closer economic relations agreements are finalised. But there is already essentially free trade between Australia and New Zealand under the present New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement, which includes berries in schedule A. I do not believe there should be too much difficulty. But for the first few years of CER with the New Zealand producers at present getting 10 per cent assistance as an export incentive and with some of them continuing to receive the suspensory loans that they have been receiving, life may be difficult for some of our berry producers. I am sure that all Tasmanian members of parliament and certainly the Tasmanian berry fruit producers will be watching this very carefully.

As I have said, we believe this assistance to the industry is justified. We believe we must watch the industry very closely in the future to make sure that it is not damaged by closer economic relations with our neighbour across the Tasman. I hope that the assistance will result in a more efficient, larger and more effective industry in this important area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I included New Zealand's figures because they are very important now and they will become more important in the years ahead. At present the processing of fruit produces about $2.25m for the Tasmanian industry. About $400 ,000 of that amount goes to the fresh fruit market. Of this total about $1.75m is actually available to the growers. I may have made an error earlier on this. The value of the fruit to the processing industry in Tasmania is about $2.25m. Of this the growers receive about $1.75m. There is no doubt that there is great potential and there could be achievements if the matter were handled properly. I am not convinced at present that the Tasmanian industry is operating under the best marketing scheme. I think this matter needs a certain amount of rethinking and reorganising. I believe the industry is not organised sufficiently to maximise potential markets. I would have to say that it is substantially hamstrung at present by the lack of plant variety rights legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I read a release from the British High Commission only in the last few days headed 'New soft fruit has promising future'. The item states that the tayberry, a new soft fruit developed in Scotland, will shortly go into commercial production. So it may, but it will not happen in Tasmania or elsewhere in Australia because of the lack of PVR. There is no way in which we can get our hands on a new variety such as that. It is said that the tayberry has performed particularly well in canning and jam making tests. It is also suitable for freezing. These are the sorts of qualities which people are looking for in berry fruits. Regrettably we do not have access to those things.

A few months ago I was able to visit some research stations in the United Kingdom. I was terribly impressed with the extensions to the varieties that they have produced which are unavailable to us. These include varieties which are appropriate for their long carriage or easy freezing qualities. Various species are appropriate for the juice market only and so on. Our industry is being held back. The Dr Doolittle community in Australia, the people who are trying to hold us back from all sorts of developments and progress, have a lot to answer for. While we are being held back, for various reasons which I do not understand, other countries are going past us. It is regarded as smart to stop industries progressing with the use of new varieties and so on which are developed overseas .

I incorporated the table showing New Zealand production because I see New Zealand as being very much a part of our future. Over the years ahead the development of our industry will be very much tied to the development of New Zealand and its industry. If honourable senators look at the New Zealand figures they will see that since 1978 New Zealand's raspberry production has doubled. Its blackcurrant production is up 2 1/2 times; boysenberries 3 1/2 times; strawberries 4 times; and loganberries and gooseberries considerably more than that. New Zealand has found that there is a market. Recently I found that gooseberries from New Zealand were being sold in Germany at $6 a kilo during their off-season market. The Bounty (Berry Fruits) Bill gives us time to catch up. It gives us time to develop, organise and work with New Zealand on establishing a sound base to trade in the off-season market of the Northern Hemisphere and to relieve the Australian market of the sudden influx of fruits which come, unheralded at times, from New Zealand. I believe that by working with New Zealand, as I hope we will from now on, we should be able to remove this problem.

At present soft fruits are coming in to Australia duty-free. This is part of the old New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Under CER they will still come in duty-free but if they can be shown to have been dumped from New Zealand or from any other source, action can be taken where necessary. I hope it will not be necessary. I hope that we will be able to work closer with New Zealand and to develop new markets instead of doubling up on the ones that already exist . I believe that there are markets in North America and East Asia and South East Asia that we should be able to capitalise on without damaging one another.

The industry has had much difficulty in overcoming a shortage of statistical information. Because it is a small industry such details have never been attended to as those in the industry would have wished. Those people involved in the Soft Fruit Industry Board have sought changes in government statistical information. I have a copy of a letter which they have written, in which they specify what they would like to have done. I wish to include some of the details of this letter in Hansard because I think it is important that their wishes be understood. They have been in touch with the Bureau of Statistics and the Bureau is investigating the possibility of providing figures in the format that they require.

They are asking specifically for five sets of figures: Firstly, specific tonnage required by the Australian market; secondly, the form in which the end user requires that fruit; thirdly, the price paid by Australian users; fourthly, from where users currently obtain their supplies; and fifthly, possible alternatives for underdeveloped uses of fruit. They believe that if they can get the necessary co-operation and have that information provided, certainly they will be better able to meet the market and supply what is required in the form that it is required.

Again I find it necessary to draw attention to the New Zealand incentives. Whilst we do not wish that type of operation to be set up in Australia, we must consider that it has placed New Zealand in a very advantageous position. I hope that with the restructuring of CER negotiations some of these benefits will come back on a reasonable basis to our growers. The bounty that we are speaking about represents about 10 per cent on factory prices in an industry that produces about 10,000 tonnes of fruit a year. Because of the location of the industry, it has many advantages in that it is labour intensive, it has good export potential , and a first class growth capacity fostered by suitable local conditions. It is an industry that deserves support. Tasmania has skilled people, small holdings and the right conditions. Certainly the industry can progress. While I support the Bill, I hope that after the five-year duration of this arrangement it will not be necessary to extend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Bounty ( Berry Fruits) Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the commencement of a very important debate because it is a debate dealing with Bills that raise very sensitive and very difficult questions. Not the least of those questions of course is the motivation of the Government in bringing this National Crimes Commission Bill forward at this time. Perhaps one of those motivations is the Government's desire to do something to rid itself of the embarrassment which has constantly been its lot so long as the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union continues to sit. Another motivation possibly is the desire of the Government to bring forward a good resounding law and order issue in time for a possible early election. But I do not think that much is to be gained and much purpose is to be served by continuing the gales of rhetoric that have attended so much of the earlier debate on this issue in the other chamber and elsewhere. I think it is time now that we got down to a fairly cool and reasoned analysis of the proposal before us and indeed treated it in the form in which it comes before us on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the issue is best approached in three parts by asking three quite different questions in succession. The first question is: Is there a need for some further and better investigative and law enforcement machinery to deal with organised crime in related areas? The second question is: If so, what is the best way of providing it? The alternatives in the debate are essentially three- fold; first, to upgrade the powers and capacity of the police; secondly, to continue the existence of ad hoc royal commissions, perhaps with some further expansion of their powers; and thirdly, to establish some form of permanent crimes commission. The third question is: If one comes down in favour in principle of the crimes commission mode as being the best of those three alternative approaches, is this particular Bill good enough?. Does it hit the target? Does it get the balance between community interests and individual rights accurate?

If I may summarise briefly at this stage, the answers which the Australian Labor Party gives to those three questions are as follows: Firstly we say, on balance, yes; there is a need for some better investigative machinery in this area than presently exists. Secondly, we say, on balance, and after carefully considering the alternatives, that we support the crimes commission concept in preference to those other alternatives. Thirdly, in answer to the question relating to whether this Bill and the crimes commission provisions contained in it are good enough, we say no, we are not happy with this Bill. We will support it on the second reading because we think the concepts and the basic spirit lying behind it are supportable but we will actively seek to amend the Bill in a number of respects in the Committee stage. If we are unsuccessful in substance in securing those amendments we will then oppose the Bill at the third reading. I will have something more to say later on the question of whether we will support the reference of the Bill to a standing committee of this Senate. But that is one option that does suggest itself in the event that it appears that the amendments that we will be proposing are either unlikely to be accepted or are not accepted.

I turn now to consider in detail the three major questions that I previously identified, beginning with the question of need. The primary evidence of the need for some better investigative mechanism is the series of reports which have been made in recent years involving royal commissions, special company investigations and, occasionally, police task forces which have amply demonstrated that a large amount of organised crime is occurring, especially in the areas of drug trafficking, tax evasion and corporate crime, which involves a considerable measure of official corruption. Further, those reports appear to amply demonstrate that existing law enforcement machinery is not very good at pinning down that organised crime and securing the convictions of those reasonably believed to be involved. The kinds of reports I am referring to-it is perhaps worth listing them-going right back first of all to 1964 are: The Cusack report to the Victorian Government on murders at the Queen Victoria Market; then more recently, beginning the run of the more up to date reports, the Moffitt Royal Commission into Allegations of Organised Crime in Clubs in New South Wales in 1974; the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs in 1980-the Commonwealth body; and the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in 1979-80-the New South Wales exercise out of which arose the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking between 1980 and 1982, which task force investigated Nugan Hand Limited and others in terms recommended by that Woodward Report, which report was recently tabled in this Parliament. There was the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which sat between 1981 and 1982 with jurisdiction conferred on it not only by the Commonwealth but also New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria. There was the report of the other Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry involving not the New South Wales Mr Justice Woodward but the Federal Mr Justice Woodward in 1982-again a joint exercise, on this occasion between the Commonwealth and Victoria. There was the McCabe-Lafranchi Special Companies Act Investigation reporting in 1982 in Victoria and, of course, finally the ongoing Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which has been sitting since 1981 under commissions vested in it by the Commonwealth and Victoria.

I do not claim that all these reports are equally impressive demonstrations, either of the existence of serious organised crime or of the need for royal commission-type inquiries to deal with it. Indeed, I have been critical in the past of the shoddiness of some of these reports, in particular, it must be said, that of the New South Wales Mr Justice Woodward in his report on drug trafficking. Certainly it is the case that others, not I, have been critical of the accuracy of other aspects, for example, of the Costigan report. I also acknowledge that the need for some further and better machinery has been disputed by a number of commentators especially, for example, the Victorian barristers, Robert Richter and Jack Lazarus in the well-publicised forum on the proposed national crimes commission which was held at the Law Institute of Victoria on 15 September this year, both of whom talked of a miscellany of existing bodies and powers and of the real immediate need being not so much the creation of new bodies and powers, rather a better analysis or a better use of facts which, by and large, are already known or already available.

With respect to those comments, which received wide attention, I think it should be acknowledged that both speakers were talking in the shadow then of an unknown body which they I think anticipated as being rather more fearsome than the body which has finally emerged in legislative guise from the Government. So it may be that the argument under those whose circumstances was a little more coloured than it might otherwise have been. Certainly, however, the police are in no doubt that the existing weaponry against serious or organised crime is inadequate. While they have not, understandably, been quick to endorse the Costigan findings so far as the lack of personnel with 'appropriate intellectual ability and training' to undergo analysis is concerned, they certainly have been quick to support other aspects of the Costigan report findings. For example, I refer to the findings relating to the absence of sufficient appropriate equipment and, more pertinently even than that for present purposes, the absence of wide-ranging powers which Costigan argued to be necessary to get ready access to documentary evidence, especially taxation and banking records, and to engage in more exploratory searches and seizures than the law presently allows and, furthermore, to demand answers to questions in circumstances which the law does not now permit.

When one weighs and balances all the claims and counter claims which are made about the need for further and better machinery in this area, the Opposition comes down, on balance, on the side of the proposition that the case has been made out both as to the existence of very significant levels of organised crime in this country and for the need for better investigative enforcement machinery to deal with it. The $64,000 question, however, now becomes: What kind of further and better machinery ought we to opt for? As I indicated previously, the options seem to reduce themselves basically to three-to upgrade the powers and capacity of the police; to continue the existing ad hoc pattern of royal commissions; and to establish some form of permanent crimes commission.

Dealing firstly with the question of the police, this is, of course, the option which appeals most to the police, who have made a number of communications both directly to members of parliament and through the media to this effect. But equally it is a course which the Opposition quite strongly resists. While we have conceded in the past a case for additional police powers, for example in the area of wire tapping in relation to certain specifically defined serious drug offences-an issue which we have been debating on and off over the last three or four years-we simply are not prepared to give the police the kind of blank cheque search and interrogation power that Mr Rippon and a miscellany of other police spokesmen have been actively seeking in recent months.

The reason for sensitivity on this subject is, I think, fairly evident. It is essentially the enormous coercive powers that are presently vested in the police ; their capacity actually to deprive people of their liberty by way of arrest or otherwise in the course of conducting investigations. We believe those powers should be able to be exercised, if at all, only in the context of the reasonable suspicion by the police of the commission of particular offences. They ought not to be allowed to be exercised by police officers possessing these coercive and liberty denying powers in the context of exploratory investigations of the kind that are necessarily involved when one is dealing with organised crime. Furthermore, there is a real difficulty in confining the powers, once granted in some limited context in the exercise, to a limited area. It has to be acknowledged, as we did in the debate on the drug crime issue and the question of electronic surveillance which there arose, that this is a practical problem in that it all too easily can come to be the case that powers granted for one purpose come to be exercised, de facto, across the whole range of police activity.

We see the real need, with respect to police powers, as being not so much to expand those powers but to codify, to define precisely and in some, but by no means all respects, to limit those powers and to limit the way in which they can be exercised. But that is itself a long debate and one that can be better conducted in the context of the continuing argument about the criminal investigation Bill.

We are not saying in rejecting the vesting of more powers in the police in the area of organised crime investigation that the police have no role at all in the investigation of such crime. A strong case can be made, as Costigan acknowledges , for relying on police task forces to work very closely with the investigative officers of a commission. Especially is that desirable, I guess, when investigations involving the crossing of jurisdictional boundaries are concerned .

Again, there is a strong case for engaging police, I would have thought, actively to carry out the on the ground investigation work rather than have those powers exercised-I am talking, for example, about executing search warrants-by non-police members of the staff of a royal commission. I say that because there does exist now in at least some jurisdictions, certainly including the Commonwealth, reasonably effective disciplinary measures for the misuse by the police of their statutory powers, disciplinary measures and proceedings which are not obviously readily available in the context of other people exercising these kinds of powers. Certainly, we would further acknowledge that a very good case can be made for ploughing further resources into the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and, furthermore, for upgrading significantly the analytical capacity, the data evaluation capacity, of the police forces, both in respect of personnel involved in these tasks and the equipment with which they operate. But we simply do not believe, to repeat, that the police are the appropriate front line agency for the new and more far reaching kind of investigative activity as contemplated in the context of this legislation.

What, then, of the second option, the continuation of ad hoc royal commissions? Certainly, royal commissions are already well endowed with powers under existing legislation, much of which such legislation has, of course, been in place right back to the turn of the century. Furthermore, the royal commission will have even more wide-ranging powers if the amending legislation that is part of this cognate debate goes through in its present form. Royal commissions have been, as the list I earlier read into the record indicates, the primary vehicles through which the whole recent run of organised crime investigations have been organised . We could clearly, as a nation, go on using this particular model. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party has been critical of attempts to wind up prematurely the Costigan Royal Commission as an exploratory investigative agency in this particular area, and certainly the Costigan Royal Commission, with its quite brilliantly innovative use of computer technology, its willingness to follow leads wherever they go, its ever expanding terms of reference, albeit much against the will of the Fraser Government, and its willingness to hand over evidentiary material to prosecutors rather than simply saving it up for final reports issued in a blaze of publicity shows, in my view, how successful an investigative agency in this area of organised crime, a traditionally organised royal commission, can be.

But there are, nonetheless, a number of weaknesses in the traditional royal commission approach which I think ought to be identified. One is the problem of continuity. Clearly, there must be some limits on the extent to which the trail, starting, in the case of the Costigan report, with the painters and dockers, can go on winding. There must be some limits to the extent to which there can be an endless series of supplementary terms of reference, endless further appropriations, and so on. There comes a point at which it becomes clear that some less ad hoc body would, no doubt, be a more appropriate body to follow particular leads or to carry on tasks, a body with clearly defined jurisdiction and with appropriate accountability mechanisms, perhaps more satisfactory than those of the Costigan Royal Commission, involved in it. But that question of continuity apart, I believe that a much more serious weakness in the traditional royal commission model is from a civil liberties point of view. The basic problem here is that royal commissions are traditionally designed to expose what are described as true facts, rather than to operate as part of the law enforcement process. I acknowledge that the expression 'true facts' is sublimely tautological, but that does tend to be the phrase which is commonly used in this area. There are no statutory prohibitions of limitations on individuals being named, causing, of course, massive detriment to their reputations in the process in public hearings and in final reports. Traditionally there has been no right to refuse to answer questions on the grounds of self-incrimination, although such evidence has not traditionally been admissible against that person in any subsequent criminal or civil proceedings.

The absence of privilege against self-incrimination in the context of royal commissions might make sense in the context of a commission inquiring into, for example, a cause of an air disaster but it seems to us to make none at all and certainly has no justification in principle in the context of an exercise designed to accumulate material satisfactorily to found criminal prosecutions. It is, furthermore, notorious that royal commissions, particularly those into aspects of organised crime, have been conspicuously unsuccessful in producing subsequent convictions, even though numerous individuals may have been named in its proceedings and report. This is damaging, in turn, not only of course to the individuals concerned but also to confidence in the system of justice. So all in all we take the view that the royal commission model can work in particular instances, as the Costigan Royal Commission appears to have done at least so far . But it is not well designed for the task of dealing with, investigating, exposing and accumulating evidence about organised crime.

That then leads us necessarily to the remaining option, which is the establishment of an ongoing National Crimes Commission. The notion of a crimes commission is not a term of art. There are certainly as many different models and concepts around, in the United States as elsewhere, as there are bodies bearing that description. But I do not think it helps the cause of rational debate to go off on the basis of some notional model of what a crimes commission might be, if that may or may not have anything to do with the kind of body which is actually being floated here and now. What we need to do is to focus, in this debate, on the kind of body which has come forward in the proposal from the Government and to try to evaluate the merits of that proposal. In this respect I think it has to be acknowledged that there are several important differences between the present proposal and the traditional royal commission model which many criticisms, including those from the lawyers organisation, seem to me to have either largely ignored or understated. The most crucial of the differences is that the Crimes Commission, in the form in which it is now being proposed, exists not to expose directly true facts, so called, or individual wrong doing through the identification of individuals and proceedings and reports; rather it is to ferret out by various means, including the search and seizure of documents on judicial warrant, the analysis of documents, intelligence information, oral evidence and, through some limited inquisitorial processes, evidence which would otherwise remain inaccessible and then to hand it over to prosecution authorities for decision as to the initiation of proceedings and the conduct of those proceedings. There is provision-inadequate provision at the moment, in our view, but I will come to the details of that later if I have time-for hearings to be in private and there is indeed some statutory encouragement for this when reputations are at stake. In this particular model which has come forward there is also an express prohibition of the publication of the names of suspects in commission reports. Taking all the aspects of the basic model that is before us into account, the ALP is, albeit very cautiously, prepared to give the Bill a second reading on the basis of those provisions as they presently stand. That ALP support does not, however, imply in any way, and I make this absolutely clear, commitment to the details of the Government legislation which, as I foreshadowed, I will get to shortly.

The basis for that support I think can be summarised very briefly by repeating, to some extent, what I have been saying so far. Our support is based on a belief , first of all, that the various royal commissions and other recent developments have demonstrated a need for more effective enforcement methods to be employed than hitherto. Secondly, it is based on the belief that the development of the necessary analytical skills within the existing police forces is likely, to put it politely, to be a prolonged and complicated process. Thirdly, it is based on a belief that if additional powers of any kind are to be exercised in this area it is safer on the whole for them to be exercised by some accountable body other than the police force which will, quite apart from any other consideration, be tempted to employ the powers in question right across the whole field of its activities. Finally, our position at the second reading stage is based on a belief that it is possible to devise appropriate safeguards in the detailed provisions of the legislation to ensure that neither a new star chamber nor a Frankenstein monster is in fact created.

I now turn to the present Bill and to the question whether it is in fact good enough in the form in which it presently stands. The Opposition sees this as being the crucial issue. We approach the Bill, I guess, from the outset from the perspective that any Bill which is vehemently opposed by, among others, Mr Russell Hinze, Mr Bill Hassell from Western Australia, Mr Tom Rippon of the Police Association and by the Law Institute of Victoria and Victorian Bar Council cannot be all bad. But nonetheless the Bill still has a number of substantial defects which I want to canvass very briefly in the short time available to me. A number of changes were made to the legislation in the House of Representatives to make it more palatable, including the removal of the obligation to produce self-incriminating documents. But not enough amendments were made to make it palatable to the Australian Labor Party. Accordingly, we opposed the Bill at the third reading stage which we will do again in the event that our proposed amendments are not substantially adopted. In the event that those amendments are not substantially adopted-let me spell it out again-or that it becomes clear in advance of the Committee stage of the debate that they will not be adopted the Opposition will move, at the appropriate time, for the reference of this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for detailed inquiry and report. It seems likely at this stage that one way or another the numbers will be found in this chamber to ensure that result.

Of the 10 amendments that we propose to move, seven are aimed at correcting matters which were adversely commented upon by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its 18th report. I will list the most important of those amendments. They are those designed, in the first place, to limit strictly the categories of offences which may be investigated to those involving organised crime, sophisticated techniques or official corruption. The trouble with the present clause 7 is that it is much too wide-ranging. It gives credence to fears about the use of the Commission as a vehicle for a renewed bout of Macarthyist hearings in this country. Secondly, our amendments will be designed to remove the power to seize material which is not properly identified in a search warrant. Thirdly, our amendments will be designed to remove the protection which is available under the law of defamation for reports of public hearings of the Commission. This appears to us to be the only practical way, short of requiring compulsorily all Commission proceedings to be in private, of ensuring that reputation destroying hearsay evidence of the kind which is not admissible in ordinary court proceedings is not given wide currency. Our amendments will be further designed to remove the additional coercive powers which now appear in clause 18 of the Bill which could result in a recalcitrant witness not just being punished by six months gaol or a $1,000 fine but also by open-ended gaoling for contempt of court. We will further be seeking to narrow the contempt of Commission prohibition to disruptive behaviour of the kind which would, in other forums, constitute contempt in the face of the court. Finally, in this list of the more substantial of our amendments, we will be seeking to reduce the terms of commissioners to two years as distinct from the present proposed five years, renewable once only so that there is a regular turnover at the top and to reduce the prospects of the Commission developing an unaccountable life of its own.

In summarising the objections to the Crimes Commission model that has come forward, it is evident that they come from three basic sources. I have dealt with the objections from the police. I think the civil libertarian objections will be accommodated if the amendments that I have foreshadowed are adopted. That leaves only the objections which have been rather noisily mounted by the States. No doubt they will be equally noisily mounted by those States righters we hear so much from in this chamber. The Labor Party's position is simply this: Provided the Commission continues to work in co-operation with joint police task forces and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and that the States eventually show themselves prepared to refer authority in those few areas where the Commission will be unable to investigate fully a matter without it, we do not see formal Federal-State co-operation from the outset as being a necessary condition for the usefulness of the body. Indeed, one of the most alarming aspects of the originally floated proposals was that they involved just that-a system of joint accountability through a ministerial council which we believe would, in practice, mean a body effectively accountable politically to no one.

There is not time for me to say very much about the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill 1982. I will have to wait until the Committee stage of the Bill. I simply indicate that the Opposition, despite a number of aspects of this Bill which have generated a degree of controversy, will not oppose it. We accept the explanation of the self-incrimination provision which is contained in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and which will, no doubt, be the subject of Committee stage discussion. We do, however, oppose those aspects of the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill which raise the same points as those in issue in the National Crimes Commission legislation. Indeed our objections to things like the search warrant power and the imprisonment for contempt power are stronger in this case because of the very different character of royal commissions and the proposed National Crimes Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading of the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982 and the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill 1982. I indicate that I am in general support of the Government's propositions that it should set up a National Crimes Commission and strengthen the powers which royal commissioners have. As I will indicate in my speech, I have certain considerable reservations about some of the provisions of the Bill. I have listened with interest to what Senator Evans has said on behalf of the Opposition. I find very little that one can challenge in the criticisms that he made and the general proposition he put forward for establishing the need for such a body in this country. I think it is important in the first place to say that I consider that there has been inadequate discussion of these Bills among Government senators. The way in which hurried decisions have been made about the Bills and decisions delayed about whether there ought to be amendments is a matter of some concern to me. It puts me in a particularly awkward position. I received this morning a bulk of material relating to the matter. In my capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills I have not had the opportunity to be given advice from the counsel that advises that Committee. I expect to be much more informed about that situation and about the extent to which the Government's responses to our criticisms are satisfactory by tomorrow morning.
—We will not be going beyond the second reading.

—I understand that. I am very relieved to know that. There is obvious need for further discussion about the terms of this Bill. I think it is important though to deal with the general propositions contained in this Bill. It is useful to outline the purposes of the two Bills because I think they tend to be forgotten in some of the criticisms that are made. The National Crimes Commission Bill sets up a body which has the function of investigating organised crime and official corruption with a view to prosecution action where appropriate. The Government further maintains that while the Bill provides for investigation by the Commission of breaches of Commonwealth law, provision is also made for participating States to give the Commision functions relating to the investigation of offences against State law. Criticism can be made of the Bill in that it relates, of course, essentially to Commonwealth law. But, as is said, it gives the States the opportunity to participate in this course of action.

SPEECH.PARA: The other purposes of the Bill are, of course, the investigation of offences and the assembly of evidence with a view to prosecution. The Commission may also be authorised to conduct investigations of a more general character and nature relating to criminal activity and to make reports and recommendations thereon to government. The Bill gives the Commission important powers necessary to its functions. However these powers are made subject to appropriate safeguards to protect the rights of individuals. Whether the safeguards are appropriate is the subject of very considerable discussion by a number of groups in the community, including law bodies, civil libertarian bodies and individuals who are concerned that rights under the law should not be abandoned.

The second Bill which we are dealing with in this cognate debate amends the Royal Commissions Act. The principal amendments to that Act are made to provide that those royal commissions whose letters patent so provide are to have certain additional powers. Firstly, there is to be the power to issue certificates that witnesses have refused or failed to comply with certain requirements. Where such a certificate is given the Federal Court or a Supreme Court may, on the application of the Attorney-General, inquire into the case and order the person to comply with the requirement. Secondly, the Commission may apply to a judge of a prescribed court for the issue of a search warrant where, among other things, it believes a thing connected with a matter in respect of which it is conducting an inquiry might be concealed or destroyed if a summons were issued for its production. In circumstances of urgency an application for a search warrant may be made by telephone. That was an amendment which was added, I think at the suggestion of the Opposition, in the House of Representatives.

Other major amendments made by the Bill deal with the privilege against self- incrimination, extend the power to issue summonses to require the production of non-documentary material and provide protection to counsel assisting or appearing before the Commission. Royal commissions will also be empowered to communicate information that relates to or may relate to the commission of an offence or afford evidence of the commission of an offence to various Commonwealth and State authorities. Provision is also made for functions or powers conferred by State authorities under State laws upon the Commission to be performed or exercised in conjunction with the performance of its functions or powers under the Royal Commissions Act.

I think it is important that we appreciate the scope of these two Acts. They have quite a lot in common; indeed they have some problems in common. Senator Evans has made out what I believe is a sound case for the establishment of a national crimes commission and he has investigated the alternatives that have been suggested. In particular I refer to the idea that it would be sufficient to increase the investigatory powers of present law enforcement bodies. I do not think that this answers the problem, particularly in relation to organised crime in this community. I accept the fact that it is established that a very substantial degree of organised crime seems to be beyond the power, and perhaps in some cases even the will, of enforcement bodies in the various States. I believe that the public of this community is calling for action which will be at least as efficient as organised crime bodies which, of course, operate willy- nilly across State boundaries and are not in anyway restricted by federalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, do you believe that such a commission would avoid the failure of the Kennedy assassination commission? That commission was a flop.
—I could not form a conclusion on that. I think that such a commission would be more successful-
—I mean we could learn from the United States errors.

—There is a most extraordinary conglomeration of commissions in the United States. Some are private and some are formed for quite specific purposes. I believe that the proposed commission would be more efficient. We have had the example of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which is sometimes criticised but to my mind it is doing a very substantial and important job in this community. That is a royal commission. However, one could imagine that a national crimes commission operating in a similar way would turn up many things and provide evidence for prosecutions which otherwise would not be obtained by State bodies. So far as the case for a crimes commission is concerned, Senator Evans referred to the number of bodies which have pointed out over many years the deficiencies of existing organisations dealing with organised crime. I do not propose to repeat the names of those various commissions but I do want to refer to a couple of remarks which have been made by royal commissioners, in particular the Williams Royal Commission on Drugs in 1980. The Commissioner had this to say about the alternative to law enforcement agencies:

SPEECH.PARA: Law enforcement regards its functions as discharged once the individual is arrested and charged in respect of a particular offence. To say these things is not to criticise law enforcement agencies in the performance of their duties. The criminal law in Australia is ill equipped to deal with any 'organised basis' of illegal activities-establishing the 'organised basis' will have no consequence so far as the law is concerned.

Therefore I think we must recognise that something over and above the existing law enforcement agencies is needed. More recently the Costigan Royal Commission, in its interim report No. 4, set out a number of reasons which show there is a need for something of this nature. In particular, I think it is important to recognise the following comment made in the report about existing law enforcement agencies:

They do not have sufficient personnel of the appropriate intellectual capability and training to undertake that difficult analysis of facts which is necessary to identify major criminal organisations. In part I believe this is attributable to a reluctance by police forces to recruit graduates from Universities directly into their criminal investigation branches. The reluctance springs out of fierce opposition to recruitment at officer level. The opposition is difficult to justify, particularly when one takes into account that it has been the practice in the military forces for a very long time. The opposition will have to be defeated if police forces are to have available to them in sufficient numbers men of the appropriate intellectual calibre to match those who are in the criminal organisation. It is sufficient to draw attention to the academic qualifications of . . . to make the point that the criminal organisations do not suffer from the same disadvantage.

It is also pointed out that at present State police forces are not properly equipped to do these things and also that they lack power and are confined to traditional methods which have not made them successful in achieving these results. I believe that there is a strong case for a crimes commission in this country. But it is important that we consider the details of that crimes commission and that we do not abandon at the same time the rights of individuals in this community which have taken hundreds of years to accumulate and which are still essential to them. We must not be panicked into removing those rights.

One of the things that has been raised in criticism of the proposed body is the fact that it will be purely a Commonwealth body. I know that negotiations have taken place with the States and I am sorry that after a long time they have not come to the party in reaching agreement on this matter. I hope that they will take up the options in this Bill which make it possible for them to co-operate. Even if a number of States co-operate that in itself will be very valuable. It is my belief that when one creates a crimes commission of this nature it is not a matter of interfering with some essential State powers. We are dealing here with a hiatus of State powers; we are dealing here with all the grey areas. People engaged in criminal conspiracy and with unlimited money are able to run roughshod over the weaknesses of limited State organisations. I hope that the Commission will be seen in that light by the States and not in the light of providing some sort of objection to them.

We must recognise that in recent years there has been undoubted corruption in some State police forces. Unquestionably, even at a high level, there have been persons who have not pursued the fight against organised crime. I believe that some of the objection that comes from police bodies relates to a desire not to have interference in their internal affairs. Perhaps it may highlight activities and lead to some embarrassment. I do not say that in a general way about the police forces of this country but I believe that to some extent there is that fear. Some of the corruption that has been revealed by various royal commissions around the States-royal commissions which one need not enumerate but which are probably very close to our minds-concerns the failure of the police to observe proper standards of conduct. These are matters that indicate that we cannot rely entirely on the police forces of the States to achieve the necessary and desirable results.

While this debate has been going on there has been some strong criticism, particularly by legal bodies, of the proposed Crimes Commission. In the early stages I think some of the criticism was a little demented and excessive. I believe, as I think Senator Evans does, that when the protections that are written into the Bill are seen, some of the earlier comments which suggested that we might be returning to the days of the Stuarts or star chambers will prove unjustified. At the same time we must be careful that there is no ground for such criticism. One of the big concerns has been about whether such a commission will meet openly or secretly. The Bill provides that the Commission may sit in secret. In many cases I think that is desirable to protect reputations and secrets which people properly have. It also provides that their wishes shall be taken into account. Of course, those wishes may be overridden.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a genuine attempt to find an accommodation in a difficult area.

—Yes, it is a very difficult thing to reach an accommodation in this area. Consequently, I think the more discussion we have about this the better to try to ensure that we do not overbalance it. It is true that this Bill provides for a five-year term. I think, the Australian Labor Party wants a two- year term. Assuming the appointment is for a limited period nonetheless great damage could be done to individuals in that time if we are not careful. I think we must carefully test the balance between secrecy and openness in regard to the investigation of people, because many of these investigations will be fishing expeditions. Royal commissions have a fixed term of reference. The Crimes Commission may find itself turning-as the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union found-its inquiry into different and surprising areas. Of course people called before the Commission will be examined in different ways.
—It is a four-year or five-year term.
—I think a five-year term is sensible.
—I am pointing out that the Labor Party does, too.
—The term in the Bill is five years, is it not?
—The term is two years for individual appointments but five years for the Commission.

—Yes, I see. Some of the concerns expressed by the law bodies perhaps deserve more consideration than they have been given. There have been discussions in regard to self-incrimination and the difference which existed between the production of documents and persons being required to give individual evidence that might be incriminating. There have been changes. I understand that the Government will be moving a further amendment in this area. From my reading of it, it seems to me to have some common sense about it. I would like to see the details of it. The law bodies are concerned that a person called before the Commission might not know of the area in which he is to be examined.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown) in his response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills pointed out that the principal target of investigation-that is, the person likely to be charged-should not be questioned. When the examination is commenced, very often it will be difficult to say who that will finish up being. Of course, such a person who has to come before the Commission and decide whether he requires counsel does not know whether he will be asked to give information merely of some use-in which case he need not expend a great deal of money on counsel-or whether he will be questioned on the basis of malicious information given to the inquiry which would totally embarass him publicly. The open-ended nature of this matter and the fact that people who are asked to appear get no knowledge beforehand are serious concerns of the legal bodies. They have not been answered yet.

The Australian Labor Party's foreshadowed amendments to the Bill raise a number of concerns. I think one needs to look carefully at them. I certainly will do so before determining how I will vote on them at the Committee stage. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee in its eighteenth report-Senator Evans has already referred to this-set out a considerable number of problems. I stress again that the Committee highlights matters that are referred to it. It does not form concluded views. It raised certain matters some weeks ago. As of this morning I had received a response from the Acting Attorney-General on matters relating to both Bills. That response went to our counsel, Professor Pearce, this morning. I hope that tomorrow morning the Committee will have a chance to discuss and settle a report, which should be presented here by tomorrow afternoon. That will set out the ministerial response and will say in which areas that response satisfactorily answers the queries raised and nominate those areas which are still open for serious consideration by the Senate. In that way we might be able to narrow the source of dispute which could arise. As honourable senators will see, the time factor here is very short. Therefore, it is made very difficult for me, as Chairman of that Committee, to go into details of criticism. That criticism covers such matters as the functions of the Commission, search warrants, the provision for passport seizure, hearings and their openness, the problems relating to a spouse who may be called to give evidence, and false and misleading evidence which is raised an which can be an offence before the Commission. It also covers contempt and secrecy provisions. These matters need to be considered seriously by us in Committee.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee likewise has reported its concerns about the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill. The Government was concerned with what is known as the Hammond case. That is a case in which the High Court of Australia ruled that a royal commissioner could not ask a person already on charges questions which might incriminate him. The High Court left open the question of whether, if that person were not on charges, those questions might be asked. The Government is resolving this by requiring such a person to answer if no charges are in existence. I think that has to be carefully considered in the light of the long history of British law.
There was a very satisfactory debate on these two Bills in the House of Representatives. It is not often I pay tribute to the House of Representatives for having a good Committee debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are exceptions to the rule.

—There are always exceptions. In this case not only did the Opposition perform well but also Mr John Spender and a number of other Government members moved amendments, some of which were accepted. I think the Bill was truly improved by the amendments. However, I am certainly not happy about one of the amendments which was rejected by the other place. That was an amendment in regard to costs. I propose to move the same amendment as that moved by Mr John Spender in the other place in respect of the provision of costs and where the Commission thinks it is suitable that person appearing before the Commission should be awarded costs. I believe that if people are expected to do their public duty, to spend their time appearing before the Commission and to employ counsel they should be able to recover their costs. It is not to be conluded that all the people who come before the Commission will be crooks, rogues and vagabonds. Of course they will not; many will be worthy citizens expected to spend days appearing there. I will say more about this when the amendment is debated. That amendment should have been accepted in the House of Representatives. It was supported by a number of my colleagues in my Party. I certainly propose to press it again in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The other amendments are in the melting pot. Discussions about these amendments by Government members will take place as late as this evening. Of course, the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills will meet in the morning. I believe we must overcome some of the problems that have arisen in this legislation because of the hurried way in which it has been formulated and brought before the Parliament and because of the limited time in which members of the Parliament have had the opportunity to consider it to date. On the other hand, I believe that this proposed Crimes Commission is a very necessary institution which the Parliament should have. I am, therefore, not happy to see a delay in the implementation of the legislation. I hope that the Government will look very carefully at the legislation and accept some of the more essential amendments proposed by senators from various parts of the chamber. If this is not done then I am afraid that insofar as concern has been expressed about the maintenance of the rights of Australian citizens we may have to look at the Bill further and a little more slowly. I hope that in the next 24 hours there will be a continuing, searching and worrying look at the provisions in the two Bills to make sure that they are adequate and do not wipe out the progress, success and glory of the provisions that protect individuals in the community. I support the second readings of both Bills and hope that, with some amendments, they will have a successful passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the state and extent of organised crime in this country are such that there has to be a response of some sort to the growing problem that obviously exists. But the Opposition, correctly I believe, poses the question whether the establishment of a National Crimes Commission is a totally adequate and correct response. We need to say that because we have some doubts about whether the Government, in proposing the National Crimes Commission has really grasped the nettle in respect of organised crime in this country. The establishment of a similar organisation in the United States of America, for example, has not, in any way, shape or form, resolved the problem of criminality at the top levels of society which has been paramount in that country for most of this century. In fact, evidence is certainly available to show that the more the industrialised countries develop and the more capitalist economies develop, the greater the extent of corruption, unfortunately at the top. It does not matter whether it is the United States, Japan, Italy, West Germany or now Australia; there is this phenomenon of the development of white collar crime and a growing incidence of this sort of activity. I think it flows from the fact that the value system upon which we base our society is one that believes that making or accumulating money is the most important feature. While that value system operates there will be probably tens of thousands of people in this country prepared to engage in activities that enrich them at the expense of others. Nowhere does this legislation attack that aspect of criminality.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not matter what royal commissions we establish or what evidence is available, there is a growing incidence of people attempting to accumulate money at the expense of others. After all, when this Government established the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to look at waterfront crime the Commission finished up considering crime at the top level. It finished up considering tax evasion which was being carried on by wealthy sections of the community. Last week and in preceding weeks 23 senators-I think the largest number of senators to be involved in a debate in more recent years-took part in a debate on taxation legislation, justifying or criticising the legislation. That legislation was about white collar crime and wholesale tax evasion by people with assets who wanted to evade their responsibilities. I put them in the same category as those who rob organisations to which they belong such as the financial institutions and the houses of commerce. I put them in the same category as drug runners, bank robbers and employers stealing from their organisations which has been so much a feature of recent years.

The growth of white collar crime has been alluded to consistently by people involved in the investigation of crime in our community. I recall statements made almost annually by people such as Mr Clifford, the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, who pointed out growing incidences of white collar crime in Australia. What is this Government's attitude to it? It is the establishment of yet another bureacracy. I think there is enough evidence to indicate that some of the existing bureaucracies have been penetrated by the criminal element. It has penetrated various law enforcement agencies and other agencies established by this Government such as the Narcotics Bureau, sections of our police forces and other agencies. Under the guise of protecting the community from crime people have been able to penetrate and infiltrate those organisations and carry on their nefarious activities.

We have to accept the fact that within our society there is wholesale corruption which occurs mostly in the white collar area. It occurs in professional groups who see nothing wrong with evading their tax responsibilities and who spend their time with accountants and lawyers who advise them how to avoid their tax responsibilities. This has become evident by the consistent appointment, at both Commonwealth and State level, of royal commissions. The Commonwealth- New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking has investigated the problem of drugs in Australia and how it has penetrated our business community. I see no evidence to show that drug trafficking has penetrated the trade unions, the working class centres. Certainly, there is abundant evidence that it has penetrated the business community. Consequently, that Task Force has had the herculean task of attempting to obtain evidence of the degree of involvement of officials in the drug running that has taken place in this country. The Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Stewart Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking and the Costigan Royal Commission have pointed out the inadequacy of skilled staff and resources to combat white collar crime. So whose responsibility is it if it is not the Commonwealth Government's responsibility to make sure that there are adequate trained and skilled personnel to fight this evil that exists in our society? The establishment of another organisation to do this will not necessarily resolve the problem. Will the establishment of another bureaucracy give us the skilled personnel referred to by Mr Costigan and other royal commissioners? In my State of New South Wales we have had the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, investigating a degree of organised crime in that State.

In respect of each of those royal commissions, one has to say that governments have fallen down on their tasks. Without exception in every case governments have been asked, subsequent to the establishment of the royal commissions, to extend their terms of reference. Why was it not done in the first place? Why was there such reticence? Why did we have such terms of reference that put constraints upon the investigations into the subject matter of those royal commissions? It is suggested that by the establishment of a National Crimes Commission the problem will be resolved. This is in the face of opposition from all of the States. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, said:
The impression is that everyone's at it, one way or another.

It is probably overemphasising it to say that everybody is at it. Plenty of people in the Australian community are not attempting to amass money and fortunes by acts of criminality. Nevertheless, because people highly placed in our society are at it, one gets the impression that everybody is. Mr Everingham went on to say:

Public servants are running escort agencies, doctors are burning the midnight oil falsifying Medibank claims. The professional accountant is in league with the lawyer building whole business empires in the murky depths of various harbours.

It is clear that Police Forces across Australia need greater powers to investigate, and bring before the courts, people whose activities have only been revealed by the lengthy and expensive procedures of Commissions of Inquiry.

These revelations lead us to ask what is wrong with our criminal justice system when it apparently allows serious crime at the highest and best organised levels to go undetected by normal investigation procedures.

That raises a very important point. If we look at the speeches made by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, and by Mr Lionel Bowen on behalf of the Australian Labour Party, we see that Mr Newman admitted what we have been asserting-that is, Mr Hayden, Mr Bowen and I-in respect of Nugan Hand. It was involved in drug running and gun running. I will quote from what Mr Newman said when he presented the report of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking. I quote from House of Representatives Hansard page 2857 of 9 November. Mr Newman said:

The report contains compelling evidence that Nugan Hand, in its many manifestations, paid little regard to the laws of the land and engaged in illegal and criminal activities. In particular, it knowingly laundered and moved money internationally for drug traffickers.

What was the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation doing while these sorts of activities were being carried out by the Nugan Hand organisation? It was more concerned with whether Arthur Gietzelt was talking to a member of the Socialist Workers Party, a National Civic Council member or a member of the Communist Party in some pub or other, following proper legal political activities, instead of really carrying out its task of investigating criminality taking place in this country. Mr Newman, the Minister for Administrative Services, who introduced this Bill in the House of Representatives, dealt with the activities of that organisation and with the activities of the Joint Task Force that was established in co-operation between the Australian Government and the Government of New South Wales to look into drug running and all of its manifestations.
