Some of the reports are so hot that they have not even been tabled or made available. Mr Newman admits that these illegal transactions occurred. What is the Reserve Bank of Australia doing? Where are the people in the community whose responsibility it is to protect us from these nefarious and subversive activities? What are they doing? We have seen a drastic increase in the amount of money given to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I have only to look at my colleague Senator Mulvihill to remember how he, together with Senator Murphy and others, was involved with activities of that organisation and the Ustashi affair during the period of the Whitlam Government. That organisation fell down on its job. It has fallen down on its job in respect of white collar crime in Australia. The defence and the security of this country is about white collar crime-drug running, gun running and other subversive activities involving currency transactions in and out of Australia. As Mr Bowen pointed out, ASIO was used to bring in dubious characters from the United States who had intelligence links in Australia with the Central Intelligence Agency--

TALK.START.PARA: —One of them even got citizenship on a very peculiar basis too .

—That is right. These gentlemen were given citizenship rights when many of us on this side of the House battle to obtain citizenship rights for persons whose only crime is that they have engaged in some form of radical activity at some stage of their lives. Yet these very dubious characters, whose records should have been known by our departments and certainly by our intelligence organisations, were given not only citizenship rights but also rights to move in and out of this country without a passport and without the normal restrictions imposed on ordinary citizens. As Mr Bowen pointed out, the first report of the Joint Task Force had to be kept confidential. I note that the Government is now saying that the matters which are the subject of the present report will be the terms of reference for the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking under Mr Justice Stewart. Mr Bowen went on to point out that it is necessary to expand the terms of reference to include the actions of international intelligence agencies and particularly those people who have been named in this report and elsewhere as being associated with those intelligence agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: What guarantees do we have in this legislation that those who give evidence to the official agencies-the police forces in our country-will be protected? We are entitled to have some concern about this legislation because we will always remember how the drug couriers Mr and Mrs Wilson gave evidence to the appropriate agency and, as a result of giving that evidence, were subsequently murdered.

TALK.START.PARA: —But to whom did they give the information?

—It was given to government agencies, to government agents. I mention also Mr Volkman who came to me and who subsequently I put on to Mr Bowen , who dealt with his case in great detail in the House of Representatives. Mr Volkman gave evidence in camera and then received a visit from the Australian Federal Police at which they took his notes. He was subsequently forced into a position where he lost his job with a Commonwealth agency and found himself persecuted by our Attorney-General (Senator Durack). He was forced to go into the supreme court to defend his good name when he was framed in respect of a so- called transfer out of Australia of protected species of birds. When the matter went to the court the judge laughed it out of court. Nevertheless, this gentleman gave evidence because he believed that intelligence forces were involved in white collar crime. It was part of his duty as a member of the Narcotics Bureau. He has been persecuted ever since he gave that evidence and he stood to lose not only his job but also substantial sums of money in trying to protect his good name. Naturally the Australian Labor Party is concerned about the civil liberties involved in this question of a National Crimes Commission. If one dares to go before a National Crimes Commission to expose the obvious degree of corruption that is at the top level of our society one must protect not only one's good name but also one's life. Let us have no bones about it at all. Knights of the realm are involved in this activity. They come and go at their pleasure because the agencies in this country turn a blind eye to their activities. Because they have a handle to their names they are looked at with less suspicion than ordinary citizens who-as we saw in the report of the Commissioner of Taxation-were prosecuted and fined for their couple of thousand dollars worth of tax evasion, whereas the big fish not only got away with it but also in some respects were defended by people in high places. It is no wonder that we have lawyers.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been somewhat surprised at the extent of representations that have come to us over the last month or so since the Government made its decision, in defiance of the State Attorneys-General. Every State Attorney-General or chief officer has expressed reservations about the legislation and said that it is not adequate, that the existing law enforcement agencies are adequate to carry out the task. Those representations have come from police associations, whose integrity I am prepared to accept even though I think there are a few rotten apples in some of the police organisations and the agencies, but one does not throw the baby out with the bath water. When we receive representations from legal associations, lawyers societies and police associations expressing reservations and when there is a unanimous view that the States do not believe the establishment of this organisation is the answer to the problem, then we are entitled to ask: Why is it that the Government has sought headlines in respect of this but not been prepared to give the sort of backup assistance to the existing law enforcement agencies which could carry out the task if they were given adequate resources?

We are concerned about the right of the individual, who probably does transgress at some stage but then realises the enormity of that transgression and seeks to redress the misdeed and to give evidence. One is not confident that this legislation will protect that person. I believe somewhere between 30 and 40 investigators from the corporate affairs commissions in both Victoria and New South Wales are continually investigating white collar crime. Those bodies, and the personnel in them, are looking at the corporate criminals and the people who are using their positions in society to enrich themselves at the expense of their fellow persons. Where is our similar organisation? Are we suggesting that the National Crimes Commission can fulfil that function? What sort of co- ordination have we got? It has been suggested to me by some of the Attorneys- General that we have inadequate organisation, co-ordination and resources to carry out the task that is at hand.

As was indicated we will be moving a range of amendments which seek to protect the right of the individual and to take into account criticisms that have been made by the States and by some of the persons concerned with fighting crime and those who are concerned about the civil liberty aspect. I heard Senator Missen suggest in his contribution that the Government take on board sufficient of those amendments to allay our concern about the civil liberty aspects and about the weaknesses that exist within the legislation. If they are not accepted in the spirit of which the amendments have been put the Opposition will find itself having to vote against the third reading, not in an expression of obstruction, which is the favourite word that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) uses if the Senate exercises any powers of revision or review of legislation, but because we genuinely believe that the proposals that are embodied in this legislation are not adequate to deal with the problem. There is nothing in the legislation about the recommendations of the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union or the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which constantly refers or alludes to a lack of human resources and funds and the inadequacy of the existing agencies because of Commonwealth government policy with regard to fighting criminality and organised crime in this country.

During the hearing of an Estimates committee I asked the Deputy Superintendent of the Australian Federal Police, whether the Police had adequate resources to deal with the Medibank fraud or other frauds that were taking place. He was interrupted by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who answered in the affirmative and said that the Police did have adequate resources. Now that flies in the face of all the evidence available to us that the Commonwealth Government, in its inane and insane desire to reduce public sector spending, is removing and reducing the capacity of our law enforcement agencies to operate in the area of fighting organised crime in this country. It is because we do not believe in the sincerity of this Government that we have grave misgivings about the legislation .

While I am on my feet I will refer to another of our agencies which concerns me , as it did Mr Clyde Cameron, a Minister in the Labor Government. I am talking again about one of our own intelligence organisations which also ought to have been involved in the detection of white collar crime and intelligence gathering and the operation and transfer of large sums of finance in and out of this country. I refer to the Australian Security Intelligence Service, which Mr Cameron exposed because of its activities in our embassy in Santiago during the period of the Allende Government. Evidence has been produced in the last few days which indicates that when the Allende Government became aware of the subversive activities of the Criminal Intelligence Agency in Chile during its period in office-I emphasise that that government was a democratically elected government-the Australian Security Intelligence Service, without the consent of the Australian Government, was used as a centre for carrying out the activities that led to the downfall and the overthrow of the elected government.

So, some of those people ought to be put on trial in respect of these matters; we should not be just establishing some sort of gimmicky organisation that sounds good for those who do not really examine what the organisation is really about. It sounds nice, clean and correct to establish a National Crimes Commission in the belief that it will solve this problem whereas in fact, of course, I and many of my party colleagues believe that some of those people in those organisations and agencies which operate on behalf of a government have turned a blind eye, and in so doing are protecting the very evil of criminality which is rampant in so many of the countries in the Western world. To our everlasting discredit governments do not pay sufficient attention to the detail of cleaning out this cancer which exists within our society. It is a cancer that will weaken the democratic fabric of our society unless governments have the courage and guts to get on with the job of fighting organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the existence of organised crime in Australia as revealed by various royal commissions, task forces and investigatory bodies, the Commonwealth has proposed a National Crimes Commission to investigate organised crime. There is very little doubt that with the increasing sophistication with which crime is being carried out, particularly in that area which is commonly known these days as white collar crime, it is necessary for law enforcement agencies charged with investigating these crimes to be given the best possible environment in which to operate. A National Crimes Commission would have three fundamental features which would create the right environment. It would have certain powers which are not available to other agencies or jurisdictions. It would be able to attract, as a result of the funds which it would have, the very best personnel with the requisite expertise to deal with sophisticated crime and it would have access to the very best equipment to enable detailed intelligence gathering analysis of the type which we have seen in the Costigan Report into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has two vital assets in this area. It has the power to give to the National Crimes Commission certain rights which are not available to other agencies. Of course, it has the funds to finance the ever-increasing cost of sophisticated criminal investigations. While these assets are to be employed to fight against organised crime they are not in themselves, in my view, sufficient to ensure that the contest is successful. The Commonwealth must ensure that it has the co-operation and the active participation of the States and State criminal investigation agencies whose task it is to enforce the great bulk of our criminal laws. The Commonwealth cannot go it alone on this matter, if it genuinely expects to combat organised crime effectively. By the manner in which the National Crimes Commission Bill has been presented and prepared and by the manner in which it seeks to establish the National Crimes Commission which would operate under the terms of this Bill, it is quite clear that support from the States will not be forthcoming.

It is very important to consider the sequence of events which led to the introduction of this Bill. On 20 August this year a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council first considered the Commonwealth Government's proposal for a National Crimes Commission. The proposal was not in the form in which this legislation seeks to set up the Commission, but nevertheless it was similar to that which is being proposed. Without exception, every State and the Northern Territory rejected the proposals which were then based on the model of the United States Crimes Commission. At that meeting in Canberra a working party was set up which consisted of representatives of the Commonwealth Government, the Western Australian Government and the New South Wales Government. Those two State governments were virtually delegated to represent the other States in the working party. The resolution of the Australian Police Ministers Council meeting of 20 August acknowledged the existence of organised crime in Australia. The resolution stated that the Commonwealth's proposal was 'one possible option to be considered'. The resolution also acknowledged:
A second option advanced by Western Australia might be to upgrade and further develop the ABCI-
That is, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence-
including established links with operational law enforcement agencies throughout Australia.

On 24 September there was a combined police Ministers and Attorneys-General meeting. That meeting examined the proposals of the working party that had been prepared until that stage. The meeting asked the Australian Police Ministers Council to refine further the proposals for the multi-jurisdictional course of action-that is, a proposal involving some upgrading of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence with more emphasis on task forces to combat crime. It must be emphasised that at that point the Commonwealth was party to those proceedings and was represented on the working party. Without going into excessive detail, it was agreed that the working party would report after further refinement of its proposal by 5 November to the Police Ministers Council and to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. At that point the Commonwealth was still a member of the working party and of those subsequent committees.

On the very day that the National Crimes Commission Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives a meeting was taking place in Adelaide of senior officers of the various police forces. Those officers were putting the final touches to the working party's proposal to present to the Standing Committee. On that very day, 21 October, the Commonwealth introduced this Bill even as the working party was putting its final touches to the proposal. At that point an endeavour was being made to reach consensus amongst the States in Australia and the Commonwealth. On that very day senior police officers would have looked at the final proposal at a joint meeting and would have been ready to submit it, as arranged and agreed, on 5 November to the meeting of police Ministers in Melbourne. The proposal, was considerably different from that which is embodied in the present legislation which I shall seek to demonstrate later. But even at the time the Commonwealth was participating in the working party-for all we know it was drawing on the information that it was learning from the working party-it was surreptitiously drafting the legislation which we have before us today, in the form which the States have repeatedly, month after month, rejected and said is not acceptable to them.

The question that should be asked is why the working party's plan was not considered as it had been originally intended and arranged. If the Commonwealth had already decided that the plan was not to its liking-of course, it already knew the proposal because it was a party to the developments-why was not at least the form of 20 August adhered to? The States were delivered a fait accompli. The Commonwealth, which has only limited jurisdiction over criminal matters, has presented the States which, under the Constitution, have control over the greater part of criminal activity, with a National Crimes Commission which will run largely according to its original model with the States simply tagging along. There are indications that if the States do not approve or agree, it is just too bad; the Commonwealth will go along without them. There are indications that the Commonwealth believes that with the money it has to finance this national anti-crime body and with its sole power to authorise certain investigatory proceeding, such as telephone taps, access to taxation records, and the opening of mail, the States have no option but to join in with the National Crimes Commission in the form which the Commonwealth Government wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —We won't do it, will we?

—We will not do it. Nevertheless, there are several objections to the Commission as this legislation would establish it which do not ensure that the States will go along. As I have said already, all the States, including the Northern Territory, have opposed the establishment of a permanent crimes commission. They contend that there is no justification for creating a new investigatory body such as the National Crimes Commission and for such a body having a judicial function. There is no justification for the creation of a new police force, albeit seconded from the Commonwealth, State and Territory police forces, which will duplicate the investigative roles of the existing agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is following the United States example. When its crimes commission was first established similar justification was given at that time. It had to do with the fact that the United States Government had to involve itself in matters which transcended consideration of the States concerned. The havens for organised crime such as prostitution and gambling, with the exception , perhaps, of the importation and exportation of drugs, are matters which come within the State jurisdictions. What is proposed by this legislation is that the Commonwealth, in its jurisdiction, will come in over the top of the States' jurisdiction and do many of the things which are presently being done. In my view, that is totally unacceptable. The States and the Australian Federal Police have set up a joint task force to deal with crime where it transcends State boundaries. They have been very successful. The more notable inquiries have been the Royal Commission into the Builders Labourers Federation, the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry and the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many prosecutions have they brought?

—They are on their way. Task forces have arisen out of agreements between the various jurisdictions on the basis of need. Where they have included the Commonwealth they have on occasions been granted some of the powers which are exclusively vested in the Commonwealth and will be vested with the National Crimes Commission. I refer the Senate to the Commonwealth Government's paper on the National Crimes Commission issued by the Attorney- General, Senator Durack, in August which states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Further consideration is to be given to whether the Commission should in addition be given powers:
to have access to taxation records,
to obtain or issue warrants for the use of listening devices or telecommunications interceptors,
to instruct a witness to hand over his passport . . .'

The last of these powers is embodied in this Bill. The first was recommended especially by Commissioner Costigan. The second is already being used by the Australian Federal Police in investigations into drug-related matters, either alone or in a task force situation.

The police in Western Australia have been seeking for some time now, quite unrelated to this legislation, the same rights and privileges the Commonwealth has in respect of telephone interception-they have been doing so quite independently of the considerations which brought forward this National Crimes Commission-as a necessary extension of the tools already available to them in the fight against organised crime. They have argued, quite rightly, that it is absolutely ludicrous that only the Australian Federal Police and the Commonwealth Bureau of Customs have, and can obtain, these powers when the bulk of criminal jurisdiction is conducted by the States. Without the participation of the States the Commission which this Bill seeks to estabish will not have jurisdiction to carry out the functions for which it is designed.

The alternative, which has been supported by all the States, is to give the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence the right to seek from the appropriate authorities the sorts of investigative powers outlined by Senator Durack in his August paper. The ABCI was established by agreement in February 1981 following suggestions contained in the reports of the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking and the Williams Royal Commission into Drugs specifically to fight organised crime. The structure is already there and is capable of being further upgraded and developed. All the Commissioners of Police are on the Board of Control of the ABCI. Their function is to identify from within their jurisdiction appropriate targets for investigation. They are, after all, presumably in the best position to identify areas of criminal activity most in need of attention. The ABCI then gathers the information for the jurisdictions, either acting individually or as part of a task force. I believe that that is the most logical and the only practical way in which the targets can be determined. This therefore leads one to ask: If the States opt not to participate in the Commonwealth Crimes Commission, how can this Commission expect to identify the appropriate targets in the first place? The Crimes Commission would not have access to ABCI information and without the agreement of all those participating in the ABCI it could never gain access to it. Yet, as I have said, it is the one body in Australia which is ideally suited to identify targets for investigation.

I return to the point I raised earlier. Because of the ABCI's particular unique relationship to all the jurisdictions in Australia, the advantages it has over the proposed National Crimes Commission and its relationship to other joint Commonwealth-State-police arrangements, such as the National Police Research Unit and the proposed national institute of forensic science, it is the logical body to boost these additional powers. To fight organised crime the police need the money to counter sophisticated developments in crime and the power to carry out these investigations. There is nothing complicated about that. One needs money for the right personnel and the right equipment. One needs the power to gain access to important information sources which hitherto have been denied the State jurisdictions. What is implied in this Bill and the manner in which it has been introduced, pre-empting proposals which were put forward on 5 November by that working party and the Government's recognition that any such body needs wider investigative powers, is that the only way the States can get these powers and the necessary funds is to join the Commonwealth National Crimes Commission. If the States were to do so they would be creating an anomalous situation in respect of the Constitution by giving to the Commonwealth, through its National Crimes Commission, jurisdiction over criminal matters which the Constitution left in the hands of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will want traffic control next.

—That is right. Without State participation the National Crimes Commission needs the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence to function in a broad domestic sense. Agreement for that will not be forthcoming from participants in the agreement which set up the ABCI. That was clear from the reactions of the Western Australian Minister for Police, the Queensland Minister for Justice and, indeed, the Australian Federal Police Association. The comments of the Secretary of that body are particularly appropriate here. Mr Curtin, when asked about the National Crimes Commission, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: While it may reveal organised crime in Australia, what happens afterwards? It has to go back to the police. It seems it's duplication of the judicial system.

Of course, that is exactly what it is. It is a duplication of what is already in place, which needs only some upgrading and strengthening to do what is intended to be done by this legislation. Within the agreement by which the ABCI was set up there was scope for it to be broadened, particularly in respect of its field operations. Presently it does not have an operational wing. It is purely an intelligence gathering body that relies on information being fed into it by the Commonwealth, State and Territory police forces. It then disseminates that information to various jurisdictions. It could of course, be broadened to give it an operational wing and it would then do precisely what the National Crimes Commission is intended to do. But of course it would have the States' support. The structure would be very different in one way-it would have the support of all the States.

The legislation before us today would create a commission which is a Federal commission answerable to the Federal Attorney-General. To operate effectively it needs the States to cede their jurisdiction so that both the Commonwealth and the States have jurisdiction over general criminal matters. Without exception, the States and the Northern Territory have said that they do not want a Commonwealth crimes commission. In accordance with agreements on these matters which are already in operation and by which co-operative interstate arrangements have functioned for the last two years, they want a combined body. They are seeking a commission, a task force, or whatever we like to call it that belongs to all governments, just as the ABCI belongs to all of its participants, just as the national research body belongs to all governments and just as the new Australian Police College and the Institute of Forensic Science will belong to all governments equally. In my view, they are proof of the success of co- operative arrangements operating under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers Council. No one government, State or Federal, has control over these bodies that have arisen out of these joint arrangements. Similarly, with the proposed upgrading of the ABCI, nobody would have control over it and it would be guaranteed its independence and freedom of action so that it would be seen to be beyond political control. As it is proposed, the National Crimes Commission will have the power to initiate investigations of its own volition or at the behest of the Federal Attorney-General or the Attorney-General of a participating State. But the Federal Attorney-General alone, under this legislation, may, and I quote from clause 12 of the Bill:

. . . give direction or furnish guidelines to the Commission, including directions or guidelines with respect to the priority to be accorded by the Commission to particular investigations or classes of investigations . . .

By that power the Commonwealth alone would have the ability to deter the Commission from certain investigations on the pretext of a greater urgency with respect to another matter. I put this forward as a hypothetical proposition. It may be that the real intent of any government to deter a crimes commission from a particular source of activity is to ensure that it does not uncover something and cause that government embarrassment. I put it to the Senate that that limitation on the scope of action of the Commission as it is proposed by this legislation, and under the original proposal of the States for an upgraded ABCI run jointly by all its participants, could not occur. It could not occur because the likelihood of collusion amongst all participants to deter the Commission from one particular investigation is so remote as almost to be quite impossible.

In the time remaining to me I should like to direct my remarks briefly towards the working paper which was being developed by the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I have indicated and I remain convinced, and I understand that the States remain convinced, that the best way to tackle organised crime is through an upgraded ABCI. However, at the meeting on 20 August it became apparent that the Commonwealth would not accept anything less than some sort of commission structure. Therefore, having regard to the political realities of the day, the working party set about reconciling the States' views with the Commonwealth's requirements. As a result, the working party produced a form of upgraded ABCI to be responsible to the Police Ministers of each State and of the Commonwealth, either directly through a ministerial crime council or an intermediate office attached to the Australian Police Ministers Council. In this way the Police Ministers would be able to discharge their normal functions across the broad spectrum of law enforcement with the added assurance of co-ordinated advice available to them from the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. Of course, the task forces attached to the ABCI to give it an operational wing would have the investigative powers necessary for this upgraded structure to be effective. The real departure from the original State notion was a special joint commission concept. Under this concept, special commissions would be set up with the existing powers of royal commissions, including the power to subpena witnesses and documents, the enabling powers which I have already mentioned, and the power to deal with contempt and to compel witnesses to co-operate. These commissions would have joint jurisdiction, multi-disciplined support units drawn from police officers, supplemented as necessary by Crown law officers, accountants, forensic scientists, tax experts or whoever was considered necessary to assist the commissions' inquiries.

But there would have been three crucial differences between this proposal and that which is embodied in the legislation before the Senate today. In effect, these three differences summarise why the States are all objecting to the National Crimes Commission proposal as it has been put forward by the Federal Government. First, it would have been a joint effort, jointly run and it would have been required to report to all participating governments. Secondly, it would have its jurisdiction by virtue of its participants being equally involved in the running of the commissions and would, therefore, not offend against the proper division of powers as laid down by the Constitution. Finally, and most importantly-this covers one of the most serious objections which the States and the Northern Territory had to the Commonwealth's original proposal-it would not have been a standing royal commission-type structure but rather one that was brought into being as the need arose.

There is also one crucial operational difference between the two proposals; that is, that the special joint commissions would refer matters to normal courts to prosecute. Again, as a concession to the Commonwealth, it was agreed that prosecutors could be used as consultants and, in particular cases, prosecutors could work with the special joint commission with a view ultimately to undertaking the prosecution. The proposal in this legislation is for the prosecutor to be an integral part of the Crimes Commission appointed under the recently enacted Special Prosecutors Act to handle prosecutions arising from the Commission's operations. The tradition that there is a need to preserve the integrity of the prosecutors by keeping them distinct from the investigation process in my view has not been taken into account.

In my view the proposal before us is not a good one. The manner in which it has come before us, in an apparent breach of an undertaking given at the Australian Police Ministers Council, leads one to have initial doubts about the legislation . The fact that the proposal ignores virtually all the objections unanimously raised by the States and the Northern Territory which have both had jurisdiction and vast experience in criminal investigation matters has led to very serious deficiencies. I am not sure those deficiencies will be overcome. I have serious reservations about the immediacy, the urgency, of this legislation. The fact is that by 5 November this year there should have been a complete, comprehensive and presumably co-ordinated report presented by all States, the Territory and the Commonwealth to the satisfaction of all. Now we find that this legislation is rushed through the House of Representatives and the Government is now seeking to rush it through the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to vote against it?

—I will keep my options open. That is an entitlement I have as a Liberal. I am sure we all recognise the need for a Crimes Commission. I think we recognise the need for an effective Crimes Commission-one that embraces all jurisdictions, one that has the capacity to go beyond Commonwealth legislation which is very limited in terms of its scope relating to criminal matters and one which has good will and co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States. Perhaps in the minds of honourable senators opposite this is a unique occasion on which there was good will, good endeavour and good intent, and good progress was being made towards ensuring that the States and the Commonwealth finally came up with a model that satisfied everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a misnomer to name this body the National Crimes Commission. Of course it is not. It is a Commonwealth crimes commission and it is intended to bulldoze the States, by the methods I have outlined, into falling into line. I suspect that they will not. If the participants of the original 1981 agreement- the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence-decline to provide this Commission with the repository of the knowledge that body has gathered over the years I think the Commission is going to be a damp squib. The only way that I can see without that goodwill that information being made available is through the insidious leaking of that information from the Australian Federal Police. I find it very regrettable, when it is vital that we have the right legislation to embrace all jurisdictions for the purpose of fighting national crime which is becoming-to use somebody else's expression-almost of epidemic proportions, that we now have legislation rushed through the chamber which deals in a very limited , imprecise and inadequate way with national crime.

I have not made up my mind where my position will finally be when the Bill is put to the vote but it would give me a great deal of comfort if I thought that the Government had the common sense, the wisdom, the will and the good will to defer this legislation until such time as there have been further proper, meaningful negotiations with State governments, particularly given the good will that the State governments and the Territories have offered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne has given a short history of the relationship between the present Federal Government and the States in relation to the creation of this National Crimes Commission. Unfortunately, as he has outlined, he has the misfortune to give his allegiance to a government which is arrogant and contemptuous in its disregard for the States and the proper consultation processes that should have been undertaken. I agree with that. It appears, from what Senator Crichton-Browne has told this chamber, that for some months the national Government cloaked its real intentions whilst keeping the States running around in working parties thinking they were achieving some concensus, certainly at the officials level.
—At ministerial level.

—And even at the ministerial level. I have some sympathy with the concern that Senator Crichton-Browne expressed but I do not think that that should obscure what merits there are in this legislation. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne has not made up his mind on this legislation. I hope that he admits at the end of the debate that there is sufficient good in the National Crimes Commission Bill, which is designed to establish a National Crimes Commission to investigate criminal activities-in particular organised criminal activities-with a view to prosecution of offenders, to merit his support. I believe that it does merit the support of the whole chamber; not uncritical support but general support. I believe there is no doubt that there is a need for a nation-wide mechanism to challenge what is a nation-wide problem.

SPEECH.PARA: No one can seriously doubt that Australia is experiencing a type of criminal activity, a range of criminal activity, which is very skillfully organised. No one would expect that criminal activity to have regard to, to be curtailed or hindered by, State boundaries. There is no reason why in response the community should feel it ought to be hindered or restricted by reference to institutions, whether of police investigation or law enforcement activities, which grew up from colonial and then State developments. The tentacles of organised crime are national and this Parliament needs to respond in the face of evident failure of existing police investigation and law enforcement authorities. They have failed. They have an institutional framework based largely on State boundaries. They have not countered the upsurge in crime. Something new is needed and many and various royal commissions have pointed to that need. Senator Arthur Gietzelt's speech was a full listing, a very efficacious listing, of those reports, the constant theme being that some national mechanism was needed to counter national organised crime.

It is a fact that whilst in the Bill there is a proposal for a National Crimes Commission, State police forces and State law enforcement authorities will not be supplanted; they will be supplemented. Indeed, I believe that the Federal- State police task forces and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence can be strengthened. Indeed it can be noted that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his second reading speech undertook that further resources would be provided to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. That is to be welcomed. There is no reason to suppose that those arrangements cannot be strengthened. Certainly there is no reason to suppose that this legislation will supplant them. In fact a cursory reading of the Bill indicates the intention that the highest degree of co-operation ought to obtain between the National Crimes Commission and the States. Thus, clause 11 of the Bill states:
In performing its functions the Commission shall-
The wording is 'shall' not 'may'; this is a direction from the Parliament--

so far as practicable, work in co-operation with the Australian Federal Police and the Police Forces of the States and any other authorities or persons responsible for the enforcement of the laws of the Commonwealth or of the States .

The Parliament, if it passes the Bill, intends as a mandatory direction that the National Crimes Commission seek co-operation with the State police forces. As Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, it is true that the States are encouraged to use the facilities and organisation provided by the National Crimes Commission. Thus, clause 8 reads:

. . . the Commission shall perform any functions in relation to the investigation of an offence or offences, however described or referred to, against the laws of a State that are conferred upon it by or under any law of the State.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the approval of the Federal Attorney-General.

—No, far from it. I will come to that in a moment. A State parliament could pass a law conferring jurisdiction on the National Crimes Commission. I believe that will occur as the State communities, their police forces, their law enforcement agencies, their governments and their populations, gather in confidence concerning the functions of the National Crimes Commission. It is not to be forgotten that whilst it is true that State police commissioners and law enforcement officers now have some misgivings about the creation of a National Crimes Commission I understand that the idea was first put forward by Victoria's Chief Commissioner of Police, Mr Miller. He saw it as a means of tackling organised crime in Australia. As I said, he first floated the idea. I do not believe the motion is without support at the highest levels of the police and law enforcement authorities. I concede that the manner of its being brought into this Parliament is a reflection perhaps of the obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). As I said, that ought not to obscure the merits of the Bill and the fact that in its terms it is directed to allowing a co- operative growth with State law enforcement authorities in order to tackle organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not forget the primary functions of the National Crimes Commission. It is true that it is limited to investigating circumstances suggesting an offence against a Commonwealth law or a law of a Territory. That is its primary jurisdictional boundary. Thus one would be able to deal with the importing of drugs or criminal conspiracy to defraud the revenue or social security, or something like that. What it is designed to do is to enable a full attack to be mounted against organised criminal activities; that is, offences that appear to be connected with one another and involving several offenders and substantial planning and organisation. It is required to look at tackling offences involving the use of sophisticated methods, planning or techniques. Finally it is directed to have regard to activities relating to bribery or corruption involving officers of the Commonwealth or of a Territory. There its primary jurisdiction is laid out.

We do have something before us which is innovative. Basically it is inquisitorial with very wide investigative powers. It is continuous and it has non-specific terms of reference. The jurisdiction I have outlined is really its terms of reference. It is true that directions and guidelines can be given to the Commission by the Federal Attorney-General. I think that the misgivings that Senator Crichton-Browne had about that clause may be laid somewhat at rest by a fuller reading of the clause. The honourable senator read that part which states :

The Attorney-General may, by notice in writing to the Commission, give directions or furnish guidelines to the Commission, including directions or guidelines with respect to the priority to be accorded by the Commission to particular investigations or classes of investigations but the Attorney-General is not entitled to give directions or furnish guidelines in relation to the conduct of a particular investigation.

The point that Senator Crichton-Browne made remains: By asserting that perhaps the importing of drugs has priority over the investigation of fraud in relation to the Commonwealth revenue, the Federal Attorney-General might thereby effectively remove resources away from an area which, for some reason, he may not want to pursue vigorously or robustly. But clause 12 (2) continues:
Where the Attorney-General gives any directions . . . the Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the directions or guidlines to be published in the Gazette .

These are not secret guidelines. They are written guidelines published is the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Therefore, they will be immediately exposed to public observation and criticism if necessary and certainly will be exposed to the critique which may be offered by those in this chamber who might wish to bring them forward at Question Time or in fuller debate. Once again, if the States decide to come into the National Crimes Commission framework and use the facilities which will be available, the Federal Attorney-General cannot establish a priority which puts a State matter, given to the Commission by the State, at the botton of the list without the consent of the State Minister concerned. In all those ways I think that there is some protection against the sort of abuse which Senator Crichton-Browne rightly alerted us to. But, as I said, the innovation in the creation of the National Crimes Commission would be the substantial investigative powers that it would be given. I have already outlined that its substantial jurisdiction is to investigate any circumstances suggesting that an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth may have occurred.

It is not true to say that this Bill creates a royal commission with a five- year term. The whole direction of the National Crimes Commission is towards prosecutions whereas royal commissions are fact finding exercises on the whole. They have been notoriously inept even when they have suggested that prosecutions should be undertaken against certain persons whom they have named specifically in their reports. It has been a well known fact that very few prosecutions have succeeded because royal commissions have not been concerned to gather and assemble that level of evidence which would satisfy a court.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sometimes wrong, too.

—If it is not wrong then certainly, as I said, they have not achieved that level of proof which might be required to secure conviction beyond reasonable doubt. The National Crimes Commission, having investigated an alleged offence, is directed to assemble with a view to the prosecution of the offender, any evidence of the commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory that it obtains in the course of its investigations and to furnish such evidence to the Australian Federal Police, to the Attorney-General or to a person nominated by him.
—Are they more infallible than the others?

—No. Their job is to assemble the evidence, then to hand it over to the Federal police or the State police, as the case may be, or, in other instances, to the Federal Attorney. No doubt, in those instances, a special prosecutor would undertake the assessment of the evidence and the prosecution that might be required. But there is no doubt that in this role of investigation , with all of the resources and facilities available to it, and in assembling evidence, always mindful of the need to assemble such evidence as might lead to successful prosecution, we have quite an innovation on the Australian scene in our desire to combat organised crime. There are some dangers. It is true to say that the Opposition has had as many misgivings as others. We will seek to ensure at the Committee stage that certain basic liberties are not put at risk, that reputations are not wrongfully or needlessly destroyed and that the Commission is fully accountable to the democratic political process. But I think we should freely concede in this chamber that the Government has already made certain clarifications, concessions and modifications in the course of the public and parliamentary debate. To that extent I believe that, insofar as it has so responded, the Commonwealth Government deserves some praise.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at some of the differences between the proposed National Crimes Commission and the traditional forms of royal commissions, we find that in this Bill the Crimes Commission is given the discretion to conduct its hearings in private. Of course, this will be entirely appropriate where there is a possibility of prejudice to the ultimate fair trial of a person. Hearings will be conducted in private where there is a danger that the reputation of a person may be needlessly destroyed or that a fair trial at an ultimate future date might be prejudiced.

In relation to self incrimination, which I know is a concern of many honourable senators, there is a substantial meeting of many of the criticisms that were originally levelled at the concept as it was then known. Now a person appearing as a witness before a commission is not entitled, without reasonable excuse, to refuse or to fail to answer a question that he is required to answer by the member presiding at the hearing. Further, he may not refuse or fail to produce a document that he is summoned to produce. But it is a reasonable excuse that to answer the question might tend to incriminate. So where a person alleges that to answer a question or to produce a document might incriminate him, the Bill states that he is entitled to silence; he need not answer unless the Attorney has guaranteed his immunity from prosecution in relation to that point. In that way we have a reasonable response by the Government to the misgivings that many people have. Further, in its public reports the Commission is enjoined and required not to identify the identity of a particular person if to reveal that identity might prejudice the safety or reputation of a person or the fair trial of a person who has been charged with an offence.

So in many ways the Government has already moved a long way to satisfy those who had misgivings about some of the civil liberty aspects which were under some threat by this Bill. As I said, this Bill represents an innovation in our public life. It is not surprising that it has taken some public and parliamentary debate to refine the Bill. There is still room for something that Senator Crichton-Browne pleaded for so eloquently. There is still room for the Government to make a further amendment which would permit us to vote for the third reading of the Bill. Whilst the Opposition will support the Bill in principle at the second reading stage, it will press amendments which it thinks may further protect individuals why may be caught up in this process before the National Crimes Commission. If those amendments are not substantially accepted by the Government, we will reluctantly have to oppose the Bill at the third reading. But there is still time for negotiation.
For those who have serious and genuine doubts about the establishment of such a commission I think clause 39 (1) of the Bill can be of some solace. That clause reads:
This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of 5 years after the date of the commencement of the Act.

So there it is very clear. The fact is that this Parliament, the House of Representatives and the Senate-the two chambers-will have to re-create the National Crimes Commission in five years time if it is to continue. It will naturally expire five years from the date of commencement of the Act. So there will be deliberate debate in both chambers on whether to reinstitute the Commission. As I say, we will have to revive it with legislation passed through this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think the Government's intent is that five years hence the principles of the Sermon on the Mount will prevail and we will not have all these rorts? Perhaps that is what it thinks.

—I think even a good Catholic would have to concede that after 1, 982 years the Sermon on the Mount has really not penetrated the social mores. I think another five years is probably too short a space of time to expect it to succeed completely. Within those five years Senator Crichton-Browne's misgivings might prove to be misplaced. That period will give the States, their police forces, their law enforcement agencies and their Attorneys-General time to observe the operations of the Commission, to co-operate with it and to give it references from time to time. Over those five years I believe some confidence might be built up. It would be wrong to deny to the nation this innovation, this new weapon within our institutional armoury to fight organised crime. This chamber ought not to deprive the community of this weapon. The National Crimes Commission ought to be permitted to accumulate experience, expertise, and the trust and confidence of the police and law enforcement authorities of the States and the Northern Territory. Naturally they are cautious, but I believe that natural caution can be overcome. In fact I believe the five-year clause gives the National Crimes Commission and the Federal Attorney-General every incentive to make sure that trust and confidence are created over the five years between now and the lapse of this legislation. But it would be a foolish, a short- sighted and hidebound Parliament which with all the protection we can afford to those who might appear before the Commission's investigations and furthering and assembling of evidence for prosecution, would deny the National Crimes Commission a five-year term of existence to help the nation fight-I repeat this- its jurisdiction. This is what we are setting up this Commission for and this is why the Labour Party supports in principle the creation of a commission. Clause 7 states that the commission shall direct its activities in relation to organised criminal activities, offences involving the use of sophisticated methods, planning or techniques; or relating to bribery or corruption involving officers of the Commonwealth or of a Territory. I believe that this is a bold experiment. It can be refined a little further at the Committee stage, but on the whole it deserves our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the purpose of the National Crimes Commission Bill? The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to establish a body . . . the National Crimes Commission which will be given the functions and powers necessary to deal with forms of crime with which existing law enforcement bodies have difficulty in coping.

What are these forms of crime? From a Press release from the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) in July of this year and from the substance of the Bill it appears that the activities to which this Commission would be directed are, first, organised crime and, secondly, corruption of officials and official bodies. It is interesting and somewhat surprising that the latter-the corruption of officials and official bodies-received no mention in the Minister's second reading speech. It would appear that it is now being down played. The Senate will recall that back in April much of the impetus for a National Crimes Commission was apparent official corruption. There were particular allegations of police corruption. Allegations were also made of political corruption. It was suggested that a crimes commission of this nature was the best way of testing such allegations. Perhaps the media saw it in the spirit of the Metropolitan Crime Commission of New Orleans which claims the ouster of three judges, a police chief and the indictment of an assistant district attorney, a sheriff and a large number of policemen.

However, the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report, and more particularly the Costigan report, have moved the emphasis not surprisingly to organised crime . What is organised crime? There are many definitions, but it is usually accepted to be a crime of a serious nature involving a number of persons utilising sophisticated techniques and methods. Warnings have been received of its nature and growth. The Senate will recall the Moffitt Royal Commission into Organised Crime in Clubs, the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-I have mentioned the interim reports-and the interim report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. What is the present position? Costigan said:
I am satisfied that the criminal organisation which is described in this report is flourishing in Australia.

That is the position in which we must approach the Bill which is before us. What is organised crime? It includes the major rackets with their base in prostitution, narcotics, pornography, loan sharking, gambling, starting price betting, casinos, organised labour, extortion and fraud. Also it may include theft, distribution of stolen property, credit card operations, housing and land swindles and white collar crime. It is said that white collar crime in the United States costs $40 billion a year. Obviously that is a cost to the total community either directly or indirectly. I have no figure for Australia but I can remind the Senate that crime prevention, according to the latest report of the Australian Institute of Criminology is said to be costing in excess of $1, 800m a year. Who are the criminals? Costigan says that they are those who supply the capital necessary for criminal enterprise-the financiers; those who provide the sophisticated services; members of professions who are prepared to deviate from professional codes of ethics; the criminal entrepreneurs who put the schemes together and, finally, the criminals who execute the schemes. In the Costigan report they are referred to in the following terms:

They may be called upon to man the hotels as SP bookmakers, to distribute drugs , or fire the gun, or use the cosh. It is they who move the containers, or remove from them the contraband, or bribe and corrupt.

These operatives are more easily identified and convicted by orthodox police methods-that is, complaint, investigation, arrest trial and conviction. But the leaders, the entrepreneurs, the professionals-lawyers, accountants, bankers, computer experts, et cetera-using modern rapid communications and sophisticated techniques are rarely identified and even less often convicted. There is no doubt that organised crime must be suppressed. I agree with Costigan when he said:
The unchecked operation of large scale criminal activity of a kind described in this report can lead only to a breakdown in law and order and the eventual destruction of the society in which we live.

The evidence of this is that we are failing in Australia. I have referred to various royal commission reports of recent times which indicate that such is the case. The onus therefore is on governments to examine their law enforcement agencies. Can they be made more effective or is twentieth century organised crime of such a nature that it requires a new approach, new methodology? The Commonwealth has decided in this instance on a new approach-a new approach necessary to supplement the existing system-that is, the National Crimes Commission. However, I ask: What are the deficiencies in the existing system? Why is it necessary to look to the development of a new system rather than the conventional?

Law enforcement in Australia is diffused, principally divided into six States, one Territory and the Federal police forces, each with limited jurisdiction and responsible to different political masters. The jurisdictions are not only divided geographically but also enforce separate criminal codes. In addition there are numerous other enforcement bodies-the Bureau of Customs, the Australian Taxation Office and the Corporate Affairs Office, to name just a few. The problems arising out of these somewhat artificial divisions are not easily overcome. To talk of a national police force with State divisions enforcing a national criminal code would, no doubt, displease many of my friends, notwithstanding its obvious merit. In addition to the problem of divisions in jurisdiction there are also the shortcomings of conventional police forces with the lack of sophisticated equipment and perhaps an insufficiently trained man force in the areas of accounting, finance and corporate law. I do not place great weight on those factors because clearly they can be overcome. However, what has become apparent more than anything else is a lack of power effectively to investigate organised crime. The proposed National Crimes Commission is really born out of the need for greater power-in particular, the power to compel evidence on oath as part of an investigation; a means of breaking the wall of silence so often faced by investigators of organised crime.

Of course, that immediately raises questions of civil liberties. Inquisitorial methods of investigation cause concern. This Parliament has a responsibility for the security of society. It also has a responsibility to protect the fundamental rights and liberties of the average Australian citizen. However, there is provision for protection against self-incrimination in this National Crimes Commission Bill. In fact it has been extended beyond that under existing law to include production of documents. People's reputations are protected. The Commission cannot name in public reports people who are suspected of committing criminal activities. It cannot publish a Hoods Who, as in the case of the Chicago Crimes Commission and as has been planned by one of New York's crimes commissions. This, of course, would be abhorrent to our system. It is also not to be a citizens' vigilante group, which is the guise under which a number of the American crimes commissions operate. Debate such as this, of course, raises questions of civil liberties. But to a large extent I am satisfied that under this Bill the problems have been overcome. Some areas of remaining concern will be dealt with in the Committee stage.

In recent times royal commissions have been successful in using inquisitorial power in the investigation of organised crime. Its value has also been shown in the case of corporate investigations. Therefore, with greater protection for the individual-and of course greater protection is necessary because the primary purpose of the proposed National Crimes Commission is to inquire into areas of criminal activity with a view to prosecution, whereas for a royal commission it is to make reports to government-it is an armament of the investigator which appears to be justified in all the unfortunate circumstances of expanding organised crime in this country.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight at the behest of the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia. That union has been involved in work on various construction and other kindred industries since the turn of the century. I think it is fitting that I should refer to documents given to me by that union, of which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has copies. A few days ago Senator MacGibbon referred to what he regarded as trade union feather bedding. The honourable senator forgot, in his comments, that members of unions such as the FEDFA work in desolate areas and some of the penalties and concessions are awarded because of the ardous work involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to documents that emanated from a meeting of a large number of rank and file numbers of the FEDFA and the Australian Workers Union in the Australian Capital Territory who felt it was time that they exposed some of the shortcomings, rorts if we like, used by employers generally in dealing with the present Federal Government. I first of all ask that the documents that were handed to me by a senior officer of the FEDFA, David Crease, be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE ENGINE DRIVER

On the 5th November, 1982, the F.E.D. & F.A.-with the A.W.U.-held a combined meeting of members employed in the Public Service in Canberra. The meeting was held at the Canberra Workers Club. There, around 900 members of both Unions met together in the common interest concerning Job Security and the erosion of their numbers by Private Contractors.

Over the past 2 years the escalation of contractors invading work areas, traditionally covered by the Public Service employees, has been dramatic. Not only are the Departments encouraging these contractors; but, they are ignoring their responsibilities towards policing these contracts and ensuring that the contractor's employees are receiving the correct rates and conditions as per the appropriate Award-handed down by the Conciliation and Arbitration Courts.

It also came to light, at this meeting, that Government material and labour was given to these contractors to help them fulfill their obligations to the Departments. Even to the extent that showers, towels, lockers and ablution facilities were given to them; tools and garages were supplied for the repair of Private Vehicles.

That the tax-payer should be made aware of where his money is being spent. Money that pays for the running of Bureaucracy's blind administrators! Does the Public of Canberra know that contractors have, and over periods of years, been occupying houses of the Department of the Capital Territory for around $19.00 per week? (Even if you had a Government House and were on the 'Dole'-you couldn' t get a rebate that would match the 'Perks' of some contractors!).
When questioned by the Union, the reply was that they could not get people to live in them.
Either the Department Heads are oblivious to what's going on-or they turn a blind eye-otherwise the Departments are run by 'Buffoons'.

This Government has proved its irresponsibility towards the ordinary worker in so many ways that sometimes I think that the worker must be a masochist-for each time he turns his rear-end he is ceremoniously kicked in it.

Government's Laws are ignored by Multi-nationals. Companies take the jobs with 'money in hand' payments-not only do the firms receive cheap labour by this method-but, are unpoliced by the Government. The Government Income Tax Department is more intent on catching the poor unfortunate worker for tax evasion-rather than enforcing a registered employer to subtract taxes where he is failing to do so.

It has become more prevalent, in the present economic climate, than ever before -by these unscrupulous employers. Not only are the 'Fly-by-night' operators taking advantage, but, Multi-national Companies are exploiting this illegal, immoral practice. I feel that an article I wrote for the F.E.D. & F.A. 'Operator ' would clearly emphasize the types of operations which have taken, and are taking, place. I, therefore, take the liberty of including it in this article for the 'Engine Driver'.
EXPLOITATION OF WORKERS

Especially since the down-turn in work, unscrupulous employers have exploited the situation. The F.E.D. & F.A. has been fighting for conditions, wages and justice for their members, against these employers. In the main, it has been ' Fly-by-night' employers who have been feathering their own nests on the sweat of operators.

It would take several chapters to expose just the conditions that they have been working under. No protection from the elements in reference to: toilets, sheds, travel allowance, NO sick leave, holiday pay or 38 hour week provision, etc. etc., the list could go on and on. It is no good complaining to the Unions when the promises of these scallywag shysters don't eventuate. It sounds good to be told: ''We can give you a job but, because of the Industrial down-turn, we have had to tender for the job for next to nothing-but we'll pay your $8-$10 per hour flat rate''. Note: No penalty rates, sickness provision, No compensation, etc., AND no tax-NO TAX. . . .GREAT you think!-BUT, wait until the TAXMAN calls. . . .AND MAN DOES HE CALL. . . . .!

I referred, earlier, that the main exploiters were small 'Fly-by-night' operators, but, it has come to the attention of the Union that a large Multi- national Company-P.D.C. Constructions, a division of White Industries-has used this method to P.D.C. Constructions N.T., again a division of White Industries, have taken operators from around Australia to the Northern Territory. There, they were informed that they would be working for $9.50 per hour flat rate. They worked most times a 12 hour shift even night shift, 6 days a week. Though P.D.C. owned all the plant on the construction site, and is registered as an employer, they contracted the work force. The conditions that they have to give their work force, where the F.E.D. & F.A. are constantly checking, far exceeds those in the N.T.

White Industries are tendering for large constructions jobs within the A.C.T. The situation, in the N.T., would not be attempted here or anywhere else because of the Union's activity. There is no excuse for a large company, or anyone else for that matter, exploiting the worker such as this. One of the provisions in their contract, that was given to them, was (7) 'The Company will make payments to you on a fortnightly basis under your construction name'. This smells of: '' Say your construction name might not be your correct name for taxation purposes' '.

But, operators who gave their correct names have been caught since for payments of $9500.00 to $17000.00 in tax. Please note the penalty for failure to pay your taxes as quoted from the A.C.T. Supreme Court:-

''In terms of A.C.T. Supreme Court interest at the rate of 10% per annum will accrue on such amounts from the date judgment is entered until final payment is made. Failure to pay could and generally does involve the following processes:
(i) Garnishee of your wages, salary or bank account.
(ii) Seizure of your goods and chattels (eg) refrigerator, washing machine, motor vehicle etc.
(iii) Bankruptcy proceedings (where indebtedness exceeds $1000.00)''

If you are working for money in hand, or a flat rate, you are cheating yourselves out of thousands of dollars. For, rest assured, your smiling boss, who takes you to the Pub and shouts you a few beers, is filling his pockets with your money. Money that should be going to the support of your family-not his. The person that has to pay the 'piper' with the taxman is you. You will be kicked in the proverbial arse, by the same boss that shouts you beer (with your money). As soon as you are sick, hurt ON THE JOB, the job comes to an end, or, you feel that you need a holiday, his tax returns etc., the list is unending.
The only protection that you can turn to is your Union. . . . . . . . . .It can be a costly lesson to you and for your family to learn.
DAVID CREASE FEDERAL & STATE ORGANISER F.E.D. & F.A. CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter this evening which I was unable to raise today because I did not get the call at Question Time. The next opportunity available to me to ask questions is the adjournment debate. The matter to which I wish to refer is the return to Australia of an ex- Governor-General. I am not going to use his title when I refer to him although I know it will appear in Hansard because of an instruction that you, Mr President, gave here last Thursday. I want people who may read Hansard to know from the outset that at no stage will I be using the title that was bestowed upon this man. In today's Age a photograph of him appears. The headline states: ' Holidaying Kerr says he will return for good.' I think one of the most interesting things in the particular article in the Age is that Tandberg, who is recognised as one of Australia's foremost cartoonists, depicts Sir John Kerr standing on the edge of a canal. A person has a bucket and is dipping some water out. The comment from Sir John Kerr is 'just a dash'. We all know that the cartoon refers to the famous Melbourne Cup meeting when he disgraced himself some years ago. When my colleague, Senator Walsh, referred to the incident in the Senate he was castigated by people who sit opposite who thought that he was engaging in untruths. Of course, those of us who witnessed the episode at the Cup meeting on television and then saw a replay at night knew that Senator Walsh was not strong enough in his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter which concerns me today is why this man, on his return to Australia from exile, has been provided with office accommodation in the Commonwealth Offices in Sydney. He is provided with chauffeur-driven cars at the taxpayers' expense. It is also reported in the article in the Age today that he is provided with a secretary and a bodyguard. What is the need for this man to be provided with a bodyguard when he returns to Australia? I know he is very unpopular but surely his life is not in so much danger that he needs a bodyguard. He says that at some future date he will return for good. I want to know whether the Australian taxpayer will have to provide him with a permanent bodyguard if he ever decides to come back and live in this country. I think it is an utter disgrace that he is provided with these facilities. In another paper today it is reported that he is provided with a Commonwealth office in London. Of course, I know that. With my persistence in the Senate, I was given that answer some time ago. In London he is provided with an office, a secretary and, I think, the use of cars. But quite apart from that he is in receipt of an annual pension of $52, 000. When he arrived in Sydney the other day he was picked up by a chauffeur- driven Ford LTD, similar to the vehicle which met him at the airport. Of course, that is the same car that picked him up at Chifley Square yesterday. When asked why he returned to Australia, he said:
Our reason for coming to Sydney is, as usual, to have a holiday and enjoy the company of our family and friends.

Here is a person who left this country in disgrace. The Government now sees fit to provide him with an office in Sydney, a bodyguard, a secretary and chauffeur- driven cars just because, as he says, he is here to have a holiday and to see his family and friends. We have a government which is daily-no doubt it did so at the Premiers Conference today-pleading for financial restraint. Yet, it is prepared to provide this man with luxurious surroundings; an office in Sydney. What is he doing there? He is certainly not carrying out any business. Perhaps he is filling in Christmas cards and posting them to his friends. He is certainly not carrying out any business on behalf of the Australian taxpayer. I am sure about that. The questions I pose tonight are: What will be the cost of his stay in Australia? Who authorised the provision of the facilities which he is using while he is in Australia? I also want to know whether the office accommodation and the secretarial staff that he is provided with in London is still in operation whilst he is absent from the United Kingdom? If it is, is he paying for that himself or will the taxpayers be liable for a double-headed bill -one for maintaining the facilities and services in London whilst he is having a good holiday with his family and friends in Australia and another for the office accommodation, secretarial staff, chauffeur driven cars and a bodyguard whilst he is in this country? Those are the questions which I pose and which I would like answered before the Senate rises.

I am sick and tired of the work force of this country being lambasted daily, from pillar to post, by a Government that says wage claims are too high that they are the real cause of the downturn in the economic situation in this country. This Government daily goes on record in the printed press, on radio and on television as calling upon the Australian work force to exercise wage restraint yet it can find any amount running into thousands of dollars, to keep this man in luxury. He has a pension of $52,000 a year which is provided by the taxpayers of this country. That ought to be enough for him and his wife.

The work force of this country is being pilloried every day and blamed for the economic chaos that surrounds us. As I said a while ago, the work force would be bearing the brunt of the blame in the other chamber today whilst the Premiers are meeting. No doubt we will see in the Press tomorrow that the Government is castigating the Labor Premiers from the three Labor States who will not lie down and agree-I hope they will not agree-to wage restraint or a wage freeze on the work force of this country. If the Government applied such restraint to some of the tall poppies in this country, particularly Sir John Kerr, who are on extremely high salaries I would agree with it. Sir John Kerr, in my view, is highly overpaid for what services he rendered to this country. I have said before in this Parliament that it would be a good thing for Australia if he were to remain in exile overseas where he said he and his wife are having a wonderful and enjoyable life. Of course he gets paid for something else. I understand that he is chairman of some company whilst he is in the United Kingdom. That salary would be on top of the $52,000 which is being provided by the taxpayers of this country. This Government stands condemned at this time when it is asking for wage restraint for providing these luxurious services for this man on his return to Australia from exile.
