TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May this year I spoke at some considerable length in the adjournment debate on the subject of the imminent deportation of Brett Anthony Collins, a subject on which my colleague Senator Mulvihill also spoke on that day. I do not propose this evening to speak at any great length on the subject but it is appropriate to mention the matter yet again because the Collins case is very much alive, if not well. The deportation order that was applicable last time round was not due to be activated before the end of May 1982 and, indeed, it has not been activated until the present time. But the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hodges, has now made very clear that he does propose to deport Collins and that this deportation will be effective more or less immediately. I raise this issue again in order to repeat my call that the Minister reconsider that decision, and reconsider it very carefully indeed. I believe it will be an unfortunate day for the community and for the system of ministerial discretion governing these deportation matters if Collins does prove to be deported.

SPEECH.PARA: I spelt out last time, at some considerable detail, my approach and what I believe is the approach generally of the Australian Labor Party on this matter, and more specifically my reasons for believing that the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, constituted in that instance by Mr Justice Davies, was less than satisfactory. The particular points from that speech that I wish to reiterate I think are crucial to the case that needs to be made and they are these: The relevant criteria for a deportation order that should be applied by the Minister are the real likelihood of recidivism, the contributions to the community which the person has made, the family ties and the social networks that the person has created and the dislocation to them that will result if the person has to leave the community in question.

I repeat the point I made on that occasion that it seems to me-indeed this was a point made by the Labor Party generally in the context of the proposed then deportations of Messrs Pochi and Barbaro-that a deportation should be made by the Minister only when the strongest possible probity of evidence is available to him of involvement and likely continuing involvement by that person in an activity which is totally incompatible with that person's continued membership of the Australian community. I find it impossible now, as I found it impossible in May, to believe, on the very large amount of material which I have scrutinised in relation to the Collins case, that that criterion, or indeed any of the other criteria that I have mentioned, could possibly be satisfied in this case.

I urge the Minister to revoke the order and to do so on the basis that the particular judicial decision on which he is so obviously relying in this case was manifestly insensitive to the basic principles which ought to be applied in this area. Consideration of deportation cases has to be done necessarily on a case by case basis. I acknowledge, as I have previously, that ultimately ministerial discretion in these matters is essential. I am disappointed that the seemingly enlightened and courageous approach of the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Pochi case has in fact disappeared. I would hate to think that the relatively small amount of controversy which that decision of his generated has forced him to retreat and to make now some capitulation to the various forces of reactionary darkness around the place at the expense, in this instance, of Mr Collins, whose case in my view is every bit as strong and indeed perhaps stronger than that of Pochi's. I make a final plea for a continuation of that enlightened approach.

If there is any suggestion-as there certainly was in the judgment of Mr Justice Davies, which I spent some time on before-that Mr Collins is being deported because he is an activist, a reformer, a critic and an embarrassment to the prison establishment or, in other words, that he is being expelled essentially for his political activities, that seems to me to be a grave indictment of this Government and the Minister and a reflection on the New South Wales Administration to the extent that that Administration has been placing continual pressure on the Federal Government to this effect. Of course, it is also a very serious commentary on the capacity of the Australian community for self- criticism.

The remaining point I want to make is that the Collins case is not simply something that is being taken up in a quixotic way just by myself. In fact, it has been the subject of representations to the Minister by an extraordinarily large number of people who are very prominent not only in New South Wales but also in the national Australian community. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The criteria against which Australia's share of the global quota established by the International Tin Council is allocated among Australian mines do not include consideration of the financial status of the mining company or the individual miner concerned. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No individual quotas have been established under the tin quota arrangements for small tin miners irrespective of whether they are established miners or are operating for the first time. However, a collective allocation, known as the small mine allocation, has been provided to enable merchants who supply tin to the domestic smelters to buy tin concentrates from small miners who do not have individual quotas. This collective allocation is calculated on the basis of the share of 1981 production held by mines in this category and for the October to December 1982 period, amounts to approximately 92 tonnes of tin contained in concentrates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

Although the full details of the promotional campaigns planned for each market are still being finalised, the Corporation has advised that it intends to employ 'below the line' campaigns (that is promotions other than large scale media advertising) in conjunction with the Australian Trade Commissioner Service and exporters to the markets concerned.

(3) The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation has as one of its major functions the overseas promotion of wine, and it is therefore a matter for the Corporation to determine the application of funds available to it for this purpose.

The Corporation is of the view that the levy imposed on wine grapes crushed, which provides funds for the Corporation, should be increased to provide additional funds for overseas promotion. There is, however, a difference of opinion within the winemaking industry as to whether the rate of wine grapes levy should be increased and the matter is still under consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Government Publishing Service currently have for sale at the prices indicated the following pamphlets in a series entitled 'Australian Farming Systems':
(a) 'Irrigation' (27 pages)-$9.50;
(b) 'The Arid and Semi-Arid Region' (28 pages)-$7.15; and
(c) 'The Subtropics' (48 pages)-$11.70.

(2) Does the Minister acknowledge that these publications are unacceptably expensive, particularly since the likely purchasers will be either individual students buying single copies or educational institutions buying multiple copies .
(3) What steps can be taken to reduce the cost of such publications, either to all purchasers or to persons or institutions purchasing them in connection with a course of study.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August 1982 (Hansard, page 99) Senator Evans asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister to a statement that she made in this chamber on 3 December 1980, in the course of defending the Government against suggestions that there were grounds for prosecution through the 1970s, in which she said:
I am able to assure the Senate that the Taxation Office has asked the Attorney -General's Department for advice but in no case has it had advice that successful prosecutions could be brought.

How does the Minister reconcile that statement with that of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, in his Press Release of 27 June 1982? Commenting on the McCabe Lafranchi report, the Treasurer said that in January 1975 the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation received an opinion from the Deputy Crown Solicitor- that is, from the Attorney-General's Department, to the effect that:
Grounds existed for prosecution under section 67 of the Companies Act and section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that proceedings could be instituted under section 367B of the Companies Act.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

There is no conflict between my comments of 3 December 1980 and comments made by the Treasurer in his Press Release of 27 June 1982. In his Press Release the Treasurer stated that the Deputy Crown Solicitor had been requested to advise whether the available evidence would support a prosecution. Advice was subsequently sought from senior counsel on the matter and, as indicated by the Treasurer, it was the opinion of counsel, not of the Deputy Crown Solicitor, that, on the basis of the material presented by the Commissioner, grounds existed for prosecution under the Companies Act and Commonwealth Crimes Act. However, the ensuing correspondence and discussions with the Crown Solicitor resulted in the Commissioner receiving Crown Law advice, in April 1979 and September 1980, to the effect that there was insufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case of 'conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth' and that proceedings under the Crimes Act and Companies Act would not be productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1982 (Hansard, page 683) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as Acting Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What action has the Government taken so far in order to prevent the tax avoidance racket among car dealers that is claimed is costing Australia $250m a year? Can the Minister confirm or deny the claim that one transaction attracted $18 sales tax on a car worth $50,000? Has the Government investigated claims that the promoter of one of the most popular schemes has made up to $300,000 a day in commission? Is the Government aware that Mr Cosmos, the President of the New South Wales Chamber of Automotive Industries, has asserted that one dealer was said to have made $3m over the past eight months? Finally, can the Minister add anything to the answer given to Question No. 1964 asked by me on 9 March? In that answer the Treasurer stated:
Administrative action has been intensified to bring matters to a head as soon as possible and this action is proving successful.
When will the Minister be in a position to justify the claims made in that answer to my question on notice?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Further to my comments on 8 September 1982 the Commissioner of Taxation has re -stated his view that none of the attempted sales tax avoidance schemes which have come to his attention in recent years successfully circumvents the existing provisions of the sales tax law.

He added that intensified investigative activity to challenge the schemes has continued. As I mentioned, raids on premises by the Australian Federal Police in order to seize documents have been conducted where necessary. A number of car dealers have received sales tax assessments in which additional tax equal to 100 per cent of the tax assessed has been imposed. In addition, the investigations have led to the cancellation of the sales tax registrations of several companies used by the promoters of the schemes. Charges under the Crimes Act have also been laid against some of the parties associated with the promotion of one scheme.
The Commissioner added that one of the results of this intensified activity is that participation in most of the known sales tax schemes now appears to have ceased.

The Government is aware of the assertions by Mr Cosmos which were widely reported in the Press. The Commissioner advised that the secrecy provisions of the sales tax law prevent him giving details of the amounts of commissions earned by any particular promoter or of his investigations relating thereto. With regard to the alleged motor vehicle transaction on which only $18 sales tax was said to have been paid, the Commissioner was unable to comment specifically. However he did advise that payments of amounts of sales tax in this vicinity, which represent a fraction of the sales tax correctly payable, do accord with the known facts of some of the sales tax schemes being investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1196) Senator Button asked me as the Minister representing the Prime Minister, without notice :

ANSWER.PARA: Is he aware of the letter written by the Prime Minister to the Treasurer on 15 July 1977, which was tabled yesterday, drawing the Treasurer's attention to a paper detailing a number of tax avoidance schemes, one of which was a Slutzkin scheme and that letter stated in part: . . . we should be looking to appropriate legislation at the earliest possible date.

In view of the fact that the Treasurer has claimed consistently that the Government only became aware of the extent of Slutzkin schemes in 1978 and 1979 , how does the Minister explain this apparent contradiction? Is it not the case that it is now clear the Government knew about these schemes in July 1977 or earlier, but took three and a half years to pass any law against them?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There is no contradiction between the letter from the Prime Minister dated 15 July 1977 and the Treasurer's statements. The paper forwarded with the Prime Minister's letter referred to Slutzkin-type arrangements, which involve the sale of shares in a company with accumulated profits. These arrangement do not involve the evasion of company tax on profits. On the other hand, the Treasurer 's statements and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act were directed at the stripping of untaxed company profits. The extent of this untaxed profit stripping activity was not evident until returns of income for the year ended 30 June 1977 were lodged. At that time, early 1978, the Commissioner of Taxation drew the Treasurer's attention to the problem. That and subsequent advice led to the enactment of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. The new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act contains measures to deal with the sale of accumulated profits that have borne primary company tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1616) Senator Gietzelt asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question without notice relating to the alcohol content of beer. As indicated in his answer, Senator Peter Baume referred to the Treasurer that part of the question concerning a lower rate of excise duty on low alcohol beer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has supplied the following information on the excise issue:

In May 1980 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety recommended, in its report on Alcohol, Drugs and Road Safety, that consideration be given to reducing the excise imposed on low alcohol beer. On 28 October 1982 the Minister for Transport and Construction tabled the Government's response to the report in Parliament.

The relevant section of the Government's response noted that there would be a road safety benefit if existing beer drinkers could be persuaded to switch to low-alcohol beer, and that the recommendation to consider reducing the excise on low alcohol beer was supported on road safety grounds. It noted that health and safety implications are taken into account in the Government's consideration of excise options and that, in response, inter alia, to the erosion of real excise rates since the previous excise increase in 1978, the excise rate on all beer was increased by approximately 15 per cent in the 1982- 83 Budget. In the budgetary circumstances, however, it was not considered appropriate to introduce a lower excise rate on low alcohol beer. Nevertheless, the Government's response to the report undertook to consider the proposal again when excise rates are next under review.

All considerations-road safety, health and budgetary-suggest that an excise differential would best be achieved by increasing the excise rate on higher alcohol beers rather than cutting the rate on lower alcohol beers.

However, the practicability of such a course, or its extension to include a third tier of higher excise on beers with a higher than average alcohol content -as seems to be envisaged in Senator Gietzelt's question-is greatly affected by administrative issues. These include the difficulties of differentiating at the excise collection point among apparently similar products, and any associated problems of substitution. An excise differential would encourage similar substitution possibilities at the retail level at a cost to the consumer and to Budget revenue. When the matter has been considered on previous occasions, these administrative difficulties have been among the factors deterring the Government from proceeding with the proposal.
